&+(cid:1) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) %(cid:30)*(cid:30)â%#(cid:29)(cid:8) (cid:29)â*(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) â!(cid:31)(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) #(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)%!/ (cid:28)!(cid:27)(B(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)%(cid:26) ((cid:29)(cid:8) *!((cid:27)!+!#â(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8) !(cid:31))%(cid:26).(cid:30)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8) !(cid:27)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) *#!(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)!+!#
 (cid:27)$(cid:30)%*(cid:28)â(cid:27)$!(cid:27)((cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)!(cid:27)$!.!$ â&J*(cid:8)#(cid:26)(cid:27)$!(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)B(cid:8)$!*(cid:30)â*(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:26)%(cid:8)$!*(cid:26)%$(cid:30)%B(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) &(cid:28)!(cid:31)â(cid:28)(cid:30)(cid:8)â(cid:28)(cid:28)â!(cid:27)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8)(cid:26)+
%(cid:30)* &(cid:28)*(cid:8)#â)â/&(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)#(cid:26)(cid:27)+(cid:30)%%!(cid:27)((cid:8)/(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:30)+!(cid:28)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8))(cid:30)%*(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8)#(cid:26)(cid:27)#(cid:30)%(cid:27)(cid:30)$(cid:8)(cid:26)%(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:8))(cid:30)%*(cid:26)(cid:27)*(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)*â(cid:31)(cid:30)
â((cid:30)(cid:8)#â(cid:28)(cid:30)((cid:26)%"(cid:8)(cid:26)%(cid:8)â++&!#(cid:28)(cid:30)$(cid:8)>!(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)*â(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:8)$!*(cid:30)â*(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:26)%(cid:8)$!*(cid:26)%$(cid:30)%(cid:8)(cid:26)%(cid:8)(cid:29)â.!(cid:27)((cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)*â(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:8)#(cid:26)(cid:27)$!(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)C

 +(cid:1) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)%(cid:30)*(cid:30)â%#(cid:29)(cid:8)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)â!&*(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:27)&"(cid:8)(cid:31)!(cid:27)!(cid:31)â&(cid:8)%!*?(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)(cid:31)!(cid:27)!(cid:31)â&(cid:8)/ %$(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:8)+(cid:26)%(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)!(cid:27)$!.!$ â&(cid:8)#(cid:26)(cid:27)#(cid:30)%(cid:27)(cid:30)$(cid:12)D

This Convention is legally binding for the states which signed and ratified it.
In December 2002, the position adopted by EU member states concerning this convention is
the following:

- Denmark, Greece, Spain and Portugal have already ratified the Convention;

- Finland, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Sweden have signed but not yet ratified it;

- Austria, Belgium, Germany, Ireland and the United Kingdom have not yet signed it.

The position of the future EU member states is the following:

- Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Lithuania, Slovakia and Slovenia have ratified
it;
- Latvia and Poland have signed but not yet ratified ;
- Malta has not signed.

For more information please visit www.coe.int.

144

(cid:9)(cid:7)(cid:27)(cid:10)(cid:9)(cid:30)(cid:4)(cid:6)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:26)(cid:6)(cid:30)(cid:10)(cid:1)(cid:5)(cid:26)(cid:10)(cid:2)(cid:1)(cid:30)(cid:7)(cid:10)(cid:2)(cid:4)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:26)(cid:25)(cid:2)(cid:10)(cid:30):(cid:2)(cid:1)(cid:30)(cid:7)(cid:10)(cid:11)

(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:6)&(cid:5)(cid:28)(cid:30)(cid:9)(cid:2)(cid:4)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:9)(cid:30)(cid:5)(cid:10)(cid:9)(cid:5)(cid:11)

1(cid:9)(cid:30)(cid:7)&(cid:11)2

(cid:1)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:23)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:15)(cid:14)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:4)*(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:11)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:25)(cid:7)(cid:22)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:14)N(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)>(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:17)(cid:15)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:16)
?(cid:23)*(cid:25)>(cid:17)@

*(cid:11)(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:24)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:11)(cid:8)(cid:13)(cid:3)11

The Council for International Organizations of Medical Sciences (Geneva) is an international,
non-governmental, non-profit organization established jointly by WHO and UNESCO in 1949.
CIOMS is representative of a substantial proportion of the biomedical scientific community.  Its
membership in 2001 includes 48 international member organizations, representing many of the
biomedical  disciplines,  and  18  national  members  mainly  representing  national  academies  of
sciences and medical research councils.  Its main objectives are:
â¢ 

to  facilitate  and  promote  international  activities  in  the  field  of  biomedical  sciences,
especially  when  the  participation  of  several  international  associations  and  national
institutions is deemed necessary;
to maintain collaborative relations with the UN, in particular with WHO and UNESCO;
to serve the scientific interests of the international biomedical community in general.

â¢ 
â¢ 

,*(cid:25)(cid:5)(cid:1)â*(cid:23)(cid:17)
Besides  work  undertaken  in  the  field  of  drug  development  and  use  and  international
nomenclature of  diseases,  one  of  the  main  contribution  of  CIOMS  has  been  the  issuance  of
international  guidelines  for  the  application  of  ethical  principles  in  various  key  areas.    Mostly
relevant  to  the  EGE  opinion  are  (cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4) *(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:11)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4) (cid:5)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4) (cid:12)(cid:6)(cid:14)(cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:4) (cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:4) ,(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:24)(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)
/(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:15)(cid:2)(cid:4)*(cid:11)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:21)(cid:27)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:4)â(cid:6)(cid:24)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:17)(cid:6)"S(cid:3)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:16) (developed in conjunction with WHO) first published in
1993.  They have been subsequently revised and updated and the new version was issued in
October 2002.

The  new  text  consists  of  a  statement  of  general  ethical  principles,  a  preamble  and  21
guidelines, with an introduction and a brief account of earlier declarations and guidelines.  Like
the  1982  and  1993  versions,  these  non-binding  guidelines  are(cid:4) (cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:14)(cid:22)(cid:11)(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:4) (cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:4) "(cid:3)(cid:4) (cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4) (cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:3);
(cid:9)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:6)(cid:21)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:21)#(cid:4) (cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:4) (cid:21)(cid:8)(cid:20)(cid:28)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:4) (cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:16);(cid:4) (cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4) (cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:26)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:4) (cid:11)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4) (cid:9)(cid:8)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:4) (cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4) (cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4) (cid:3)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:16)(cid:4) (cid:8)(cid:26)
"(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:24)(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4) (cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:15)(cid:2);  applying  ethical  standards  in  local  circumstances,  and  establishing  or
redefining adequate mechanisms for ethical review of research involving human subjects.

The new version contains (cid:10)(cid:4)(cid:11)(cid:3)(cid:20)(cid:4)(cid:22)(cid:6)(cid:14)(cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:30)(cid:30)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:2)(cid:8)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)
(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:16).    This  guideline  was  added  following  the  extensive  debate  on  the  use  of  placebo  in
clinical trials.  The debate is so controversial that no uniform view could be reflected into the
guideline.    It  is  thus  accompanied  by  an  (cid:3)D(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:16)(cid:14)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:4) (cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:24)(cid:24)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:10)(cid:7)#(cid:4) (cid:14)(cid:21)(cid:21)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:4) (cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4) (cid:8)(cid:9)(cid:9)(cid:8)(cid:16)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)
(cid:9)(cid:8)(cid:16)(cid:14)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:10)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:24)(cid:9)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:10)"(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:16)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:3)(cid:26)(cid:26)(cid:3)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:7)
(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:9)(cid:8)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:16).

========================================

(cid:25)(cid:9)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:19)(cid:6)(cid:26)(cid:26)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:23)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:15)(cid:14)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4),(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:3)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:16)(cid:4)15

*(cid:11)(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:24)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:11)(cid:8)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:4)16

The (cid:19)(cid:6)(cid:26)(cid:26)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:23)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:15)(cid:14)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4),(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:3)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:16)(cid:4)?0.@(cid:4) (cid:20)(cid:10)(cid:16)(cid:4) (cid:15)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:4) (cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4) (cid:30)77(cid:30)  to  identify and  clarify  ethical
questions raised by recent advances in biological and medical research in order to anticipate
and address public concerns.

A  report  and  recommendations  on  (cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4) (cid:3)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:16)(cid:4) (cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4) (cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:15)(cid:2)(cid:4) (cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:4) (cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:4) (cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:4) (cid:14)(cid:11)
(cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:8)(cid:9)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:16) were published in 2002.

The four main themes of the report are 8

â¢  (cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13);
â¢  (cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:18)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:3);
â¢  (cid:3)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:20)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:15)(cid:2) and
â¢  what happens (cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:10)(cid:4)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:15)(cid:2)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:7)(cid:8)S(cid:3)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:24)(cid:9)(cid:21)(cid:3)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:18).

The ethical framework proposed in this report is based on four principles:

the duty (cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:4)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:21)(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:16)(cid:6)(cid:26)(cid:26)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22),
(cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:4)(cid:16)(cid:2)(cid:8)(cid:20)(cid:4)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:9)(cid:3)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:16)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:16),
(cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:4)"(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:16)(cid:14)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:6)(cid:21)(cid:13)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:18)(cid:14)(cid:26)(cid:26)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:16) (cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:18)

â¢ 
â¢ 
â¢ 
â¢  (cid:11)(cid:8)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:4)(cid:3)D(cid:9)(cid:21)(cid:8)(cid:14)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:27)(cid:6)(cid:21)(cid:11)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:10)"(cid:21)(cid:3).

In the framework of the themes and principles cited above, a series of (cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:24)(cid:24)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:16) have
been formulated. They are summarised below:

â¢  All countries should set priorities for research into healthcare.
â¢  When research funded by external sponsors is proposed which falls outside the
national priorities for research into healthcare set by a host country, the sponsors
should  be  required  to  justify  this  choice  to  the  appropriate  research  ethics
committees in both the host and sponsoring countries.

â¢  Sponsors  should  ensure  that  provision  is  made  for  education  in  the  ethics  of
research of all of those professionals involved in research related to healthcare.

15 See also the Nuffield Council on Bioethics website : http://www.nuffieldbioethics.org
16 Note prepared by Patricia Mommens, EGE Secretariat

155

                                                     
(cid:23)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)

Genuine consent must be obtained from each participant; in some cultural contexts it may be
appropriate to obtain beforehand agreement from the community or from a family member. If a
person does not wish to participate, his/her will should be respected.

The information provided in order to assist participants in making informed choices should be
accurate,  concise,  clear,  simple,  specific  to  the  proposed  research  and  appropriate  for  the
social and cultural context in which it is being given. The process of obtaining consent and the
accompanying documentation  must  be  approved  by  a  research  ethics  committee,  and  in  the
case of verbal consent a process for witnessing the consent should be considered.
Inducements  to  take  part  in  research  (possible  healthcare  provided,  financial  compensation)
should  be  appropriate  to  the  local  context,  namely  where  participants  are  exposed  to  risks.
Decisions  about  appropriate  levels  of  inducement  will  need  to  be  justified  to  local  research
ethics committees.

(cid:17)(cid:13)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:18)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:3)

A suitable standard of care should be defined in consultation with those who  work  within the
country  and  must  be  justified  to  the  relevant  research  ethics  committees.  Participants  in  the
control group should be offered a universal standard of care for the disease being studied. If
this is not possible, the minimum standard of care should be the best intervention available for
that  disease  as  part  of  the  national  public  health  system.  This  principle  applies  also  for
preventive  measures  against  HIV/AIDS  and  for  participants  who  already  have  or  who  will
develop diseases other than the disease being studied.

(cid:5)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:20)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:15)(cid:2)

Developing  countries  should  have  in  place  an  independent  system  of  ethical  review  of
research.  The  establishment,  funding  and  operation  of  independent  national  research  ethics
committees should be the reponsibility of national governments.
Externally-sponsored research projects should also be subject to independent ethical review in
the  sponsorâs  country(ies)  in  addition  to  the  country(ies)  in  which  the  research  is  to  be
conducted.
International programmes and organisations, including WHO, should continue to expand their
current  programmes  for  establishing,  training  and  monitoring  the  development  of  research
ethics committees. Funding should be provided by bodies that sponsor research in developing
countries.

(cid:25)(cid:11)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:15)(cid:2)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:7)

Sponsors  of  research  should  require  that  the  development  of  local  expertise  is  an  integral
component  of  research  proposals  (CIOMS  Guideline  15).  Healthcare  facilities  should  be
strengthened in such a way that the new proven interventions together with the equipment

156

used can be made available to the local population. Investigators should justify to the relevant
research ethics committee why the research should be carried out if this is not possible. This
information should be communicated in the process of obtaining consent.

Researchers,  sponsors,  national  healthcare  authorities,  international  agencies  and  research
ethics committees should consider the following issues before research relating to healthcare
involving the testing of new interventions is undertaken:

â¢  The  need  to  monitor  possible  long-term  deleterious  outcomes  arising  from  the
research, for an agreed period of time beyond the completion of the research;
â¢  The possibility of providing participants with the intervention shown to be best for

an agreed period of time;

â¢  The  possibility  of  introducing  and  maintaining  the  availability  to  the  wider

community of treatment shown to be successful.

157

(cid:11)(cid:1)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:30)(cid:5)(cid:11)(cid:6)(cid:30)(cid:10)(cid:30)(cid:1)(cid:30)(cid:2)(cid:1)(cid:5)(cid:28)(cid:6)(cid:3);(cid:6)(cid:1)%(cid:5)(cid:6)(cid:5)(cid:25)(cid:5)(cid:6)<(cid:30)(cid:1)%(cid:30)(cid:10)(cid:6)(cid:1)%(cid:5)

(cid:29)(cid:26)(cid:5)(cid:29)(cid:2)(cid:26)(cid:2)(cid:1)(cid:30)(cid:7)(cid:10)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:1)%(cid:5)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:10)(cid:30)(cid:7)(cid:10)

(cid:11)(cid:1)(cid:27)(cid:28);

(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:3)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:16)#(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:21)(cid:10)(cid:15)(cid:3)"(cid:8)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:16)
(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:8)(cid:9)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:16)8
*(cid:24)(cid:9)(cid:10)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:11)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:15)(cid:2)(cid:4)(cid:22)(cid:6)(cid:14)(cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:16)(cid:15)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:26)(cid:14)(cid:15)
(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:7)#(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:8)(cid:9)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)

*(cid:11)(cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:13)(cid:6)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:4))(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:16)(cid:9)(cid:3)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:1)(cid:3)(cid:15)(cid:2)(cid:11)(cid:8)(cid:21)(cid:8)(cid:22)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:17)(cid:13)(cid:6)(cid:18)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:4)?(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:14)(cid:21)(cid:21)(cid:10);(cid:4)(cid:17)(cid:9)(cid:10)(cid:14)(cid:11)@(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)F(cid:8)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:13)

(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:5)(cid:6)(cid:2)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:1)(cid:9)(cid:5)(cid:10)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:12)(cid:12)(cid:11)(cid:5)(cid:8)
(cid:13)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:2)(cid:9)(cid:14)(cid:5)(cid:4)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:2)(cid:15)(cid:16)(cid:2)(cid:8)(cid:2)(cid:4)(cid:7)(cid:17)(cid:1)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:9)
(cid:18)(cid:5)(cid:11)(cid:8)(cid:14)(cid:1)(cid:4)(cid:2)(cid:12)(cid:2)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:19)(cid:1)(cid:9)(cid:2)(cid:8)(cid:14)(cid:4)(cid:2)
(cid:11)(cid:20)(cid:21)(cid:22)(cid:23)(cid:22)(cid:24)(cid:22)(cid:25)(cid:1)(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:1)(cid:6)(cid:28)(cid:27)(cid:21)(cid:29)(cid:25)(cid:30)(cid:22)(cid:23)(cid:31)(cid:25)(cid:1)(cid:14)(cid:25)(cid:30) (cid:20)(cid:27)!(cid:27)"(cid:23)(cid:30)#!(cid:1)(cid:12)(cid:22)(cid:24)$(cid:23)(cid:25)(cid:21)(cid:1)%(cid:12)(cid:25)(cid:31)(cid:23)!!(cid:25)&
(cid:17)(cid:23)(cid:26)(cid:25)(cid:1)(cid:12)(cid:30)(cid:23)(cid:25)(cid:20)(cid:30)(cid:25)(cid:21)â(cid:1)(cid:11)(cid:20)(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)(#(cid:22)(cid:23)(cid:27)(cid:20)(cid:1)#(cid:20)$(cid:1)(cid:9)(cid:27)(((cid:24)(cid:20)(cid:23)(cid:30)#(cid:22)(cid:23)(cid:27)(cid:20)(cid:1)(cid:14)(cid:25)(cid:30) (cid:20)(cid:27)!(cid:27)"(cid:23)(cid:25)(cid:21)

(cid:1)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:3)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:16)#(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:21)(cid:10)(cid:15)(cid:3)"(cid:8)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)
(cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:8)(cid:9)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:16)8(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:24)(cid:9)(cid:10)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:11)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:15)(cid:2)
(cid:22)(cid:6)(cid:14)(cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:16)(cid:15)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:26)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:4)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:3)

A background document prepared by Dr. Dolores Ruiz Ibarreta, Karine Lheureux and Emilio
Rodriguez-Cerezo.
August 2002

(cid:30)+(cid:1) â(cid:14)(cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)"(cid:10)(cid:15)A(cid:22)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:18)

Ethics  in  clinical  research  in  developing  countries  has  always  been  framed  by  international
guidelines.  These guidelines have shaped over the years in response to arising problems and
concerns, behaving as what Chalmers and Pettit call âthe controversy machineâ [1]. There is a
social  mechanism  that  responds  when  a  red  flag  is  raised  by  a  newspaper  or  a  community
group  on  research  that  is  deemed  unethical;  then  the  scandal  provokes  amendments  of  the
regulatory  or  guidance  framing  of  this  type  of  research.    While  this  stimulus/response
mechanism  is  not  exclusive  of  research  on  humans,  ideally,  areas  like  this  one,  with  such
strong  ethical  connotations,  should  not  be  left  to  a  reactive  mechanism  but  should  operate
more on a proactive approach.

In  1947,  the  Nuremberg  Code,  the  first  international  code  of  ethics  for  research  involving
human subjects, was formulated setting the beginning of the responsive ethical machinery.  It
was  a  consequence of  the  horrific  medical  experiments  carried  out  on  humans  during  World
War  II,  an  attempt  to  prevent  its  recurrence.  It  states  that  any  person  who  is  a  research
participant "*(cid:29)(cid:26) &$(cid:8)/(cid:30)(cid:8)*(cid:26)(cid:8)*!(cid:28) â(cid:28)(cid:30)$(cid:8)â*(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8)/(cid:30)(cid:8)â/&(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:30)H(cid:30)%#!*(cid:30)(cid:8)+%(cid:30)(cid:30)(cid:8))(cid:26)>(cid:30)%(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)#(cid:29)(cid:26)!#(cid:30)=(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)â(cid:28)(cid:8)=(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)
(cid:30)H)(cid:30)%!(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8)*(cid:29)(cid:26) &$(cid:8)/(cid:30)(cid:8)* #(cid:29)(cid:8)â*(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8)"!(cid:30)&$(cid:8)+% !(cid:28)+ &(cid:8)%(cid:30)* &(cid:28)*(cid:8)+(cid:26)%(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)((cid:26)(cid:26)$(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)*(cid:26)#!(cid:30)(cid:28)"B(cid:8) (cid:27))%(cid:26)# %â/&(cid:30)(cid:8)/"
(cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:8)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:26)$*(cid:8)(cid:26)%(cid:8)(cid:31)(cid:30)â(cid:27)*(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)*(cid:28) $"B(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:8)%â(cid:27)$(cid:26)(cid:31)(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8) (cid:27)(cid:27)(cid:30)#(cid:30)**â%"(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:27)â(cid:28) %(cid:30)."[2]

The use of placebo in therapeutic clinical trials, the focus of this review, has been one of the
points modified by historical developments.  This review will follow the trend chronologically as
the âcontroversy machineryâ moves forward.

In  1964,  the  World  Medical  Association  (WMA)  promulgated  the  so-called  Declaration  of
Helsinki,  a  list  of  principles  meant  to  provide  guidance  for  research  that  involves  human
subjects.  The  WMA  is  the  central  and  unique  global  organization  representing  physicians.
Nevertheless,  efforts  were  always  made  to  consult  as  widely  as  possible  outside  physicians
ranks so the first Declaration and its further revisions involved main stakeholders. Each revision
has brought more explicit descriptions of the ethical requirements, many times as a response to
debate over particular concerns.  Box 1 presents the dates of the different revisions undergone
by the Declaration [3].

 ,(cid:25)((cid:4)(cid:30)8(cid:4)/(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:14)(cid:16)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)1(cid:3)(cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)â(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:16)(cid:14)(cid:11)A(cid:14)

â¢  First  Declaration  adopted  by  the  18th  WMA  General  Assembly  Helsinki,  Finland,  June

1964

Subsequent amendments:

â¢  29th WMA General Assembly, Tokyo, Japan, October 1975
â¢  35th WMA General Assembly, Venice, Italy, October 1983
â¢  41st WMA General Assembly, Hong Kong, September 1989
â¢  48th WMA General Assembly, Somerset West, Republic of South Africa, October 1996
â¢  52nd WMA General Assembly, Edinburgh, Scotland, October 2000

164

Because  the  Declaration  does  not  specifically  deal  with  international  collaborations  and  in
response to concerns raised about developing countries, in 1993, the Council for International
Organizations of Medical Sciences (CIOMS) developed, in collaboration with the World Health
Organization  (WHO),  the  International  ethical  guidelines  for  biomedical  research  involving
human subjects [4], which addressed issues pertinent to the conduct of research in developing
countries.

The major changes in these guidelines, both the Declaration and CIOMS, came as a result of a
public debate over  what  some  considered  a  scandalous  use of placebo  arm  in perinatal  HIV
transmission trials.  The social machinery responded.

(cid:1)(cid:12)(cid:13)(cid:6)(cid:15)((cid:19)).0(cid:6)=(cid:19)(cid:15)(cid:12)(cid:6)5(cid:19)/(cid:16)-â/(cid:19)(cid:20)(cid:13)(cid:6)(cid:15)(cid:16)(cid:6)(cid:18)((cid:13)-(cid:13)(cid:20)(cid:15)(cid:6)%(cid:30)(cid:31)(cid:6)(cid:18)(cid:13)((cid:19)(cid:20))(cid:15)).(cid:6)(cid:15)()(cid:20)04(cid:19)00(cid:19)(cid:16)(cid:20)>(cid:6)0(cid:15)(cid:19)(((cid:19)(cid:20)*(cid:6)(cid:15)(cid:12)(cid:13)(cid:6)+(cid:16)(cid:20)(cid:15)((cid:16)-(cid:13)(0,

In 1997, the New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM) published an article and an editorial
denouncing the unethical use of placebo controls in randomized controlled trials (RCTs) in
developing countries for prevention of perinatal transmission of HIV [5, 6]. As indicated by
the Declarationâs Article II.3 of that time (now changed in the 2000 version) any clinical trial
on  human  subjects  requires  the  use  of  the  âbest  proven  treatmentâ.  At  the  time  of  the
denounced trials, AZT (zidovudine manufactured by Glaxo Wellcome17) had already been
proven  as  an  effective  treatment,  so  the  use  of  placebo  was  not  in  accordance  with  the
Declaration.  However,  it  was  then  argued  that  âbest  proven  treatmentâ  should  be
understood  as  âbest  available  treatmentâ.  From  this  point  of  view,  to  give  placebo  to  a
population that does not have access to the proven treatment with the aim of finding a truly
accessible  treatment,  should  not  be  deemed  unethical  [7].  The  publication  in  NEJM
triggered an editorial board resignation [8].

The  story  begun  in  1994,  when  the  AIDS  Clinical  Trial  Group  076  (ACTG  076),  which
involved  non-breast-feeding  women  in  France  and  US,  demonstrated  that  AZT  reduces
HIV  transmission  by  70%  [9].  This  reduction  was  observed  when  AZT  was  taken  orally
during the last trimester of pregnancy, intravenously during labor and delivery, and when
given orally to infants during their first 6 weeks. Because this treatment was found to be too
complex and too costly for many developing countries, a number of studies were done to
investigate whether a simplified short-course anti-retroviral regimen, targeted around time
of delivery, would also reduce transmission. These studies had control groups of pregnant
HIV  mothers  who  were  given  a  placebo  while  it  was  already  known  that  AZT  helped
prevent  transmission.  Discussion around  the ethics  of  using placebo  instead  of  the  âbest
proven treatmentâ in clinical trials was stirred.

Among  the  trials  conducted  to  investigate  a  short-course  anti-retroviral  regimen,  at  least
nine had received US government funding through the Centers for Disease Control (CDC)
or  National  Institutes  of  Health  (NIH),  while  five  were  funded  by  other  governments,  and
one  by  the  United  Nations  Program  on  AIDS  (UNAIDS).  The  main  trials  of  a  shortened
version of AZT treatment against placebo were conducted in Thailand and had proven to
be effective by 1997 [10].

17 AZT was first discovered in 1964 as an anti-cancer drug. First patent on the use of AZT to treat people with HIV
was  registered  in  1985  by  a  US  government-funded  laboratory.    In  the  same  year,  the  American  authorities
decided to grant to the British worldwide pharmaceutical  company GLAXO the  exclusive  licensing  rights  on  the
AZT use patent.

165

                                                     
In  the  Thailand  shorter  version,  AZT  treatment  starts  at  36  instead  of  26  weeks  of
gestation, is given orally during labor and delivery and not administered to the newborns.

Following  the  denunciation  in  NEJM,  the  US  NIH  and  CDC  published  a  response  in
defense of the trials [11]. In October 1997, investigators discontinued the use of placebos
in a NIH-funded study of two short-course zidovudine regimens in Ethiopia [12]. Then, in
February 1998, the CDC and the Thai government announced that their placebo-controlled
study  of  a  short-course  zidovudine  regimen  in  Thailand  had  shown  a  51%  reduction  in
perinatal  HIV  transmission  rates.  At  the  same  time,  they  announced  that  further  use  of
placebos  would  cease  in  both  this  study  and  another  in  Ivory  Coast.  US  government
agencies  sponsoring  clinical  trials  in  developing  countries  to  test  approaches  to  reduce
mother-to-child HIV transmissions asked investigators to drop placebo use [13]. The CDC,
NIH,  UNAIDS,  and  Franceâs  National  Agency  for  AIDS  Research  (ANRS)  called  for  an
international  dialogue  on  the  "far-reaching  scientific  and  policy  implications  of  these
findings".

The Thailand study and others in Africa finally gave enough evidence that the short-course
treatment  works  and  results  of  the  clinical  trials  were  published  in  1999  in  The  Lancet
journal [14-16]. So the debate was served, both critics and defenders of the trials claimed
that the Thai findings vindicated their respective positions:

-  Those  who  were  in  favor  of  the  trials  using  placebo  reasoned  that,  thanks  to  these
trials, the short could substitute the long AZT  regimen.    Should  the trials  have  been
required to use the long regimen, because it was the âbest proven treatmentâ and US
standard of care, they might not have taken place. This long complex treatment was
not  available  in  developing  countries  because  it  cost  about  $800/patient  while  the
short,  simplified  regimen  studied  in  Thailand  got  reduced  to  $50/patient.  This  is  of
great  importance  since  the  costs  of  drugs  are  one  underlying  reason  for  the  poor
access to treatment in developing countries18. Their position was in favor of using the
âbest  available  treatmentâ,  and  if  nothing  was  really  available  at  that  time  in  those
countries, placebo was the right thing to use.

-  On the other hand, the advocates of using always the âbest proven treatmentâ as the
control  to  compare  with a  new  one  considered  deprivation  of  a  therapy  known  to  be
effective to be completely unethical, without excuses. The non-availability  in  the  host
country is, according to them, not a proper argument not to treat the subjects in a trial.
As CIOMS guidelines state, protection given to human subjects abroad should be "no
less exacting" than those given in  sponsoring  countries.  Some  were  outraged  by  the
trials,  which  were  given  the  pet-name  of  âTuskegee  Part  IIâ  [17]  in  memory  of  the
Tuskegee Syphilis Study in US where several hundreds of syphilis patients among the
black  population  went  untreated  for  over  40  years  as  part  of  a  study  to  observe  the
natural development of the disease [18].

18 UNAIDS, Report on the Global HIV/AIDS Epidemic, June 2000
(http://www.unaids.org/epidemic_update/Epi_report.pdf)

166

                                                     
Back to the reactive ethical machinery, responses to the incident did not take long. In 1997, the
American  Medical  Association  presented  a  draft  proposal  to  the  WMA  to  update  the
Declaration to bring it, so it said, more in line with contemporary ethical thinking, whereupon the
WMA began the process of revising the Declaration19. Among the issues to be revised, the use
of randomization and placebo when justified was on the agenda. The revision process was a
long-term effort with discussions continuing at October 1998 and April 1999 WMA meetings. In
June 1999, WMA circulated a draft revised version of the Declaration (17.C/Rev1/99)

Some of the controversies in defining when and when not to use placebo during the drafting of
the revision have been extracted to illustrate the discussion that took place:

        While Article II of the previous Declaration stated that =V(cid:30).(cid:30)%"(cid:8))â(cid:28)!(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8):(cid:8)!(cid:27)#& $!(cid:27)(

Article 18 of  the proposed  revision  stated  that  =V(cid:30).(cid:30)%"(cid:8) )â(cid:28)!(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8) *(cid:29)(cid:26) &$(cid:8)/(cid:30)(cid:8)â** %(cid:30)$(cid:8) (cid:26)+
(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)/(cid:30)*(cid:28)(cid:8))%(cid:26).(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:8)$!â((cid:27)(cid:26)*(cid:28)!#B(cid:8))%(cid:26))(cid:29)"&â#(cid:28)!#(cid:8)(cid:26)%(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%â)(cid:30) (cid:28)!#(cid:8)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:26)$(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)â(cid:28)(cid:8)>(cid:26) &$(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%>!*(cid:30)(cid:8)/(cid:30)
â.â!&â/&(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:29)!(cid:31)(cid:8)(cid:26)%(cid:8)(cid:29)(cid:30)%=(cid:8),(cid:30)(cid:31))(cid:29)â*!*(cid:8)â$$(cid:30)$0(cid:12)
Article 19 of the proposal specified that =>(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:26) (cid:28)#(cid:26)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:31)(cid:30)â* %(cid:30)*(cid:8)â%(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:30)!(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:8)$(cid:30)â(cid:28)(cid:29)
(cid:27)(cid:26)%(cid:8)$!*â/!&!(cid:28)"B(cid:8))&â#(cid:30)/(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:26)%(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:26):(cid:28)%(cid:30)â(cid:28)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8)#(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)%(cid:26)&*(cid:8)(cid:31)â"(cid:8)/(cid:30)(cid:8)9 *(cid:28)!+!(cid:30)$(cid:8) (cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) /â*!*(cid:8) (cid:26)+
(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)!%(cid:8)(cid:30)++!#!(cid:30)(cid:27)#"=(cid:12)

Those in favor of the proposed changes considered that the amendment would allow research
sponsors  in  industrialized  countries  to  help  developing  countries  establish  affordable
treatments,  like  it  had  happened  with  HIV/AIDS  [19].  They  maintained  that  it  might  be
economically unfeasible for a researcher to provide the same standard of health care found in
an  industrialized  nation  to  participants  in  a  developing  nation  (as  required  by  the  previous
Declaration). The proposed Article 19 would, under certain circumstances, permit placebo use
even when a standard therapy already exists and so researchers could test new and improved
treatments in a more efficient, cost-effective manner [19].

Widely divergent was the opinion of those against the proposed changes because they were
seen  as  a  way  to  diminish  the  researcherâs  moral  and  ethical  commitment  to  protecting  the
patientâs well-being. In developing countries, the local standard of health care may be nothing;
thus,  the  suggested  Article  18  provided  an  incentive  for  exploitation:  a  cheaper  system  to
conduct biomedical research in disadvantaged areas for commercial benefit [20]. The objection
to  the  proposed  Article  19,  freely  allowing  placebo  use  as  long  as  participants  do  not  die  or
become disabled, was based first on the failure to recognize other adverse health effects that
could arise from placebo use, such as pain, discomfort or psychological stress. But second and
more important, some feared that a  literal  interpretation  of  the  proposed  revision  would  have
changed the standard from not allowing placebo use where a proven therapy exists  to  freely
allowing placebo use as long as participants do not die or become disabled as a result20.

19 American Medical Association. Proposed Revision of the World Medical Association Declaration of
Helsinki. Ferney-Voltaire, France: World Medical Association, 1997. (WMA document 17.CRev/97/A)
20 Lurie P, Wolfe SM. Letter to Dr Delon Human, World Medical Association, on Helsinki Principles.
Distributed by Public Citizen, Washington DC, March 1999

167

                                                     
With  all  the  discrepancies,  and  not  just  about  the  use  of  placebo,  there  was  no  consensus
between  national  medical  associations  (in  different  countries  the  revision  provoked  different
reactions) at the General Assembly in October 1999, so it was agreed to draft a new proposal.
In view of the situation, it was proposed by some that the Declaration should not be changed,
that it would instead be more efficient to draft new accompanying commentaries to the existing
version [21].

There was however a second attempt of revision which was finally adopted in October 2000,
unanimously ratified by the WMAâs General Assembly.  Nevertheless, it had taken 3 years of
discussions,  including  fine  details  about  language  and  semantics,  and  many  said  that  the
process has weakened the final statement. On the use of placebo in the trials, there is a new
Article 29 introduced:

Still,  after  all  the  time  that  it  had  taken  to  finalize  the  2000  version,  only  one  year  after
ratification,  further  clarification  on  Article  29  was deemed  necessary.  The  WMA  released  the
following:

(cid:22)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)#(cid:26)(cid:27)#(cid:30)%(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)â(cid:28)(cid:8))â%â(%â)(cid:29)(cid:8)(cid:16)1(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)%(cid:30).!*(cid:30)$(cid:8)(cid:21)(cid:30)#&â%â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:30)&*!(cid:27)?!(cid:8),(cid:11)#(cid:28)(cid:26)/(cid:30)%(cid:8)(cid:16)(cid:23)(cid:23)(cid:23)0

(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)(cid:6)?(cid:8)E(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:30)(cid:8)+(cid:26)%(cid:8)#(cid:26)(cid:31))(cid:30)&&!(cid:27)((cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)*#!(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)!+!#â&&"(cid:8)*(cid:26) (cid:27)$(cid:8)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:26)$(cid:26)&(cid:26)(!#â&(cid:8)%(cid:30)â*(cid:26)(cid:27)*(cid:8)!(cid:28)*

(cid:19)&&(cid:8) (cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:8))%(cid:26).!*!(cid:26)(cid:27)*(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) (cid:21)(cid:30)#&â%â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) (cid:7)(cid:30)&*!(cid:27)?!(cid:8) (cid:31) *(cid:28)(cid:8) /(cid:30)(cid:8) â$(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:30)$(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:26)B(cid:8)(cid:30)*)(cid:30)#!â&&"(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)
(cid:27)(cid:30)(cid:30)$(cid:8)+(cid:26)%(cid:8)â))%(cid:26))%!â(cid:28)(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:30)(cid:28)(cid:29)!#â&(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)*#!(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)!+!#(cid:8)%(cid:30).!(cid:30)>(cid:12)

Even with this clarification, there is still an ongoing debate and many contradictory positions on
the  placebo  (best  proven/best  available)  issue.  For  example,  the  European  Agency  for  the
Evaluation of Medicinal Products (EMEA) has released, in June 2001, a statement with regard
to  the  revised  Declaration.  In  this  statement,  the  EMEA  expresses  concern  that  a  strict
interpretation  of  the  Declaration  may  rule  out  clinical  trials  that  use  a  placebo  control  arm
whenever authorized therapeutic methods already exist. In this opinion, it is clearly emphasized
that,  as  long  as  the  ethical  nature  of  the  trials  is  ensured,  continued  availability  of  placebo
controlled  trials  is  necessary  to  satisfy  public  health  needs.    This  statement  is  somehow
contradictory with Community legislation on research on human subjects which requires that all
clinical trials are carried out in accordance with the current version of the Declaration.

168

The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) released some guidelines, in March 2001, in an
attempt to clarify that the new changes to the Declaration did not affect FDA regulations. These
regulations  permit  the  acceptance  of  foreign  clinical  studies  in  support  of  an  application  for
marketing  approval  of  a  human  $% ((cid:8) (cid:26)(cid:27)&"(cid:8) !+(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) *(cid:28) $"(cid:8) #(cid:26)(cid:27)+(cid:26)%(cid:31)*(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) (cid:30)(cid:28)(cid:29)!#â&(cid:8) )%!(cid:27)#!)&(cid:30)*

The controversy over the placebo-controlled trials also affected the drafting by UNAIDS of its
Guidance Document on Ethical Considerations in HIV Preventive Vaccine Research, eventually
published in May 200021. What the document concludes about the issue of the standard of care
and  the  use  of  placebo  (Guidance  Principle  16)  is  that  Fâ(cid:28)(cid:8) )%(cid:30)*(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:30)(cid:8) !*(cid:8) (cid:27)(cid:26)(cid:8)  (cid:27)!.(cid:30)%*â&
#(cid:26)(cid:27)*(cid:30)(cid:27)* *(cid:8) %(cid:30)(â%$!(cid:27)((cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) &(cid:30).(cid:30)&(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) #â%(cid:30)(cid:8) â(cid:27)$(cid:8) (cid:28)%(cid:30)â(cid:28)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)â(cid:28)(cid:8) *(cid:29)(cid:26) &$(cid:8) /(cid:30)(cid:8) )%(cid:26).!$(cid:30)$â.  UNAIDS
proposes  a  series  of  guidelines  to  follow  at  the  design  of  the  trials  in  order  to  reach  a
consensus on the appropriate level of care that is considered standard for each case.

In  this  context  of  broad disagreement,  the  CIOMS presented  in  January  2002  a  draft  for  the
International  Ethical  Guidelines  for  Biomedical  Research  Involving  Human  Subject  which  is
open to placebo use.  A new Guideline 11 would specify the requirements for Control groups in
clinical  trials:  V>(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:8) â(cid:8) #(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)%(cid:26)&&(cid:30)$(cid:8) (cid:28)%!â&(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) â(cid:8) (cid:27)(cid:30)>(cid:8) (cid:28)%(cid:30)â(cid:28)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8) (cid:26)%(cid:8) â(cid:8) (cid:27)(cid:30)>(cid:8) $!â((cid:27)(cid:26)*(cid:28)!#(cid:8) (cid:26)%(cid:8) )%(cid:30).(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)!.(cid:30)

â$$!(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)â&(cid:8) %!*?(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) *(cid:30)%!(cid:26) *(cid:8) (cid:26)%(cid:8) !%%(cid:30).(cid:30)%*!/&(cid:30)(cid:8) (cid:29)â%(cid:31)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) * /9(cid:30)#(cid:28)*(cid:12)(cid:8) (cid:19)(cid:27)"(cid:8) (cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:8) )%(cid:26))(cid:26)*â&(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8)  *(cid:30)(cid:8) â
#(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)%(cid:26)&(cid:8) (cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)â(cid:27)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) /(cid:30)*(cid:28)(cid:8) # %%(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8) (cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:26)$(cid:8) %(cid:30)G !%(cid:30)*(cid:8) â(cid:8) *(cid:26) (cid:27)$(cid:8) *#!(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)!+!#(cid:8) â(cid:27)$(cid:8) (cid:30)(cid:28)(cid:29)!#â&(cid:8) %(cid:30)â*(cid:26)(cid:27).  In
July  2002,  CIOMS  released  a  provisional  final  version  of  the  International  Guidelines,  which
does not include Guidelines 11.  CIOMS expects to have an agreed version of Guideline 11 to
be posted on their Web site during August 200222.

It could perhaps be said that the âcontroversy machineâ is still going on but it does not have a
clear direction to follow.

169

                                                     
$+(cid:1) -(cid:7)(cid:22)(cid:6)(cid:24)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:16)#

What are the arguments behind âbest proven treatment" and "best available treatmentâ â which
one best meets the aim of improving therapies in developing countries? Can the requirement of
a unique standard care using always the best proven treatment allow for the development of
new treatments that are affordable? The best current treatment in industrialized countries may
be non-existent in most developing countries; could this eventually be used as an âexcuseâ to
carry cheaper and simpler research? What are (or should be) the criteria for establishing the
level of acceptable treatment?

Much  energy  is  being  devoted  to  these  questions.  The  main  one  being  whether  different
conditions  abroad  can  justify  lower  standards  of  care,  especially  when  the  differences  arise
from  resource  inequities.  Opinions  are  polarized  between  those  in  favor  of  the  "best  proven
treatment  or  method"  and  those  for  the  "highest  attainable  and  sustainable  treatment  or
method":

$+(cid:30)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)*(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:26)(cid:10)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)T"(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:10)(cid:27)(cid:10)(cid:14)(cid:21)(cid:10)"(cid:21)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:24)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)U

Advocates of using the âbest available treatmentâ in trials in resource-poor countries, even if it
means placebo most of the times, argue that the âstandard of care requirementâ can undermine
biomedical  research  aimed  at  improving  global  health  [22].  They  agree  with  the  general
principle that the use of placebo when there are treatments that have been proven effective is
unethical  but  argue  that  with  increasing  disparities  in  health  care  between  wealthy  and  poor
countries, a therapy that has been shown to be effective is often unaffordable in resource-poor
settings. This is particularly true of therapeutic advances in HIV infection, which is a far bigger
health  care  problem  in  poor  countries  in  sub-Saharan  Africa  than  it  is  in  the  industrialized
countries. In these cases, the balance between potential harms and benefits of a placebo RCT
should be such that the potential benefits to the community would considerably outweigh the
harm (see Box 2).  This âutilitarianâ view (the action is right because it leads to a better situation
of happiness over misery than any possible alternative) can be applied universally [23].

The issue of placebo when there is a known effective treatment is obviously controversial and
there  is  so  far  no  international  consensus.  What  some  voices  within  this  group  claim  is  that
whether  a  placebo  arm  is  justified  in  a  trial  requires  careful  consideration  in  very  specific
contexts that cannot be simply deduced from a declaration [24].

The use of âbest available treatmentâ is seen as more pragmatic and down to earth since, in the
case of limited financial resources, allows testing new therapeutic possibilities that will actually
be useful in poor countries because the population will have a better chance to access to them.
As mentioned by Brower ([25]) when describing  the  trial  076, F*!(cid:27)#(cid:30)(cid:8) >(cid:26)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:8) !(cid:27)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)*(cid:30)(cid:8) %(cid:30)(!(cid:26)(cid:27)*
(cid:29)â.(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:26)(cid:8)â##(cid:30)**(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8)â(cid:27)(cid:28)!:(cid:7)(cid:5)(cid:9)(cid:8)(cid:31)(cid:30)$!#!(cid:27)(cid:30)*B(cid:8)â(cid:8)7(cid:23);7(cid:23)(cid:8) #(cid:29)â(cid:27)#(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8) (cid:28)%(cid:30)â(cid:28)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8) >(cid:26) &$(cid:8) /(cid:30)(cid:8) /(cid:30)(cid:28)(cid:28)(cid:30)%(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)â(cid:27)(cid:8) (cid:27)(cid:26)
(cid:28)%(cid:30)â(cid:28)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8) â(cid:28)(cid:8) â&&(cid:12)(cid:8) (cid:8) (cid:18)(cid:26)%(cid:30)(cid:26).(cid:30)%B(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) (cid:28)%(cid:30)â(cid:28)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8) /(cid:30)!(cid:27)((cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:30)*(cid:28)(cid:30)$(cid:8) >â*(cid:8) )%(cid:30)#!*(cid:30)&"(cid:8) +(cid:26)%(cid:8)  *(cid:30)(cid:8) !(cid:27)(cid:8) $(cid:30).(cid:30)&(cid:26))!(cid:27)(
(cid:27)â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)*(cid:8)>(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:29)(cid:30)â(cid:28)(cid:29):#â%(cid:30)(cid:8)!*(cid:8)(cid:31)!(cid:27)!(cid:31)â&â.  To be relevant, research must be responsive to the local
factors that affect the course of the epidemic in developing countries. It can be extracted from
the CIOMS guidelines that any product developed in the course of a clinical trial must be made
reasonably available to the inhabitants of the host country where the research took place.

170

Besides being pragmatic, this is meant to avoid exploitation: trials should be designed in such a
way and should be carried out in populations that can in some way benefit from the research.
Research  in  one  population  for  the  benefit  of  another,  more  developed,  population,  should
definitely be avoided.

,(cid:8)D(cid:4)$8(cid:4)(cid:17)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:4)-(cid:26)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10);(cid:4)â*:(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:4)T"(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:28)(cid:10)(cid:27)(cid:10)(cid:14)(cid:21)(cid:10)"(cid:21)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:24)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)U

As an example of the argumentation in favor of the âbest available treatmentâ, the guidelines
edited by the Ministry of Health in South Africa in September 2000. These guidelines for Good
practices in the conduct of clinical trials in human participants in South Africa23 have a section
dedicated  to  âEthical  consideration  for  HIV/AIDS  clinical  epidemiological  researchâ.  They
mention  that  while  anti-retroviral  therapy  is  effective  and  proven,  it  is  expensive  and  not
available in the South-African public sector. Participation in drug trials constitutes often the only
way  of  gaining  access  to  anti-retroviral  therapy.  Drug  trials  should  not  be  conducted  solely
because they facilitate access of drugs for some patients, although this may often provide very
positive benefits to the individual.

*(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:16)(cid:14)(cid:13)(cid:6)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11);(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:24)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:24)(cid:10)#(cid:4)"(cid:3)(cid:4)S(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:26)(cid:14)(cid:10)"(cid:21)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:4)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:21)(cid:10)(cid:15)(cid:3)"(cid:8)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:24)(cid:24)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:16)
(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:4) (cid:18)(cid:8)(cid:4) (cid:11)(cid:8)(cid:13)(cid:4) (cid:2)(cid:10)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:4) (cid:10)(cid:15)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:16)(cid:4) (cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:4) (cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:16)(cid:4) (cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:4) (cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:4) (cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4) (cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:18)(cid:4) (cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:4) (cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4) (cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:28)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:2)
(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:13)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:16)+

In order to reach the ethical principle outlined above, The South African government stressed
that proposals for clinical and  epidemiological  research  should be  submitted  to  relevant  local
ethics committees or to the South African Medicines and Medical Devices Regulatory Authority
for approval.

One of the key elements in the âbest available treatmentâ assertion, if as a result of a trial, a
treatment  is  provided  that  is  not  within  the  reach  of  the  country,  the  results  would  not  be
applicable  to  the  situation  in  that  country.    This  will  end  up  in  exploitative  research  for  the
primary benefit of people in other countries.

The criticisms from this group to the revised 2000 Declaration are directed against Article 29.  If
applied  literally,  this  clause  provides  no  excuse  for  the  use  of  placebo  whenever  there  is  a
proven  treatment.  This  imposes,  according  to  critics,  demands  that  cannot  be  met  in  most
developing  countries  and  creates  inconsistencies  with  other articles  of the  Declaration.    With
Article  19-  (cid:18)(cid:30)$!#â&(cid:8) %(cid:30)*(cid:30)â%#(cid:29)(cid:8) !*(cid:8) (cid:26)(cid:27)&"(cid:8) 9 *(cid:28)!+!(cid:30)$(cid:8) !+(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:30)(cid:8) !*(cid:8) â(cid:8) %(cid:30)â*(cid:26)(cid:27)â/&(cid:30)(cid:8) &!?(cid:30)&!(cid:29)(cid:26)(cid:26)$(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)â(cid:28)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)
)(cid:26)) &â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)*(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:8)>(cid:29)!#(cid:29)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)%(cid:30)*(cid:30)â%#(cid:29)(cid:8)!*(cid:8)#â%%!(cid:30)$(cid:8)(cid:26) (cid:28)(cid:8)*(cid:28)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8)/(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:30)+!(cid:28)(cid:8)+%(cid:26)(cid:31)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)%(cid:30)* &(cid:28)*(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)%(cid:30)*(cid:30)â%#(cid:29)
â because the requirements for the provision of new treatments is impossible to meet in very
poor systems.  Same with article 30 â (cid:19)(cid:28)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)#(cid:26)(cid:27)#& *!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)*(cid:28) $"B(cid:8)(cid:30).(cid:30)%"(cid:8))â(cid:28)!(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:30)%(cid:30)$(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:26)
(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) *(cid:28) $"(cid:8) *(cid:29)(cid:26) &$(cid:8) /(cid:30)(cid:8) â** %(cid:30)$(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) â##(cid:30)**(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) /(cid:30)*(cid:28)(cid:8) )%(cid:26).(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:8) )%(cid:26))(cid:29)"&â#(cid:28)!#B(cid:8) $!â((cid:27)(cid:26)*(cid:28)!#(cid:8) â(cid:27)$
(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%â)(cid:30) (cid:28)!#(cid:8)(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:26)$*(cid:8)!$(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)!+!(cid:30)$(cid:8)/"(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)*(cid:28) $"(cid:12)

23 Ministry of Health, South Africa. Guidelines for Good practices in the conduct of clinical trials in
human participants in South Africa.
Available at http://www.doh.gov.za/docs/policy/trials/trials_09.html

171

                                                     
It  is  clear  to  some  that  these  requirements  are  not  only  inconsistent  but  unachievable  in
countries  where  health  services  are  unaffordable  or  inaccessible  [26].  The  clarifying  note  to
Article  29,  released  in  2001,  addressed  these  concerns  by  acknowledging  that  a  placebo-
controlled  trial  may  be  ethically  acceptable  under  certain  circumstances  and  this  was  well
received among the critical voices [27].

An important issue is how to define âbest available treatmentâ. There should be an agreement
in advance of the research concerning this availability, and that the sponsoring agency should
ensure that  the  product  is  made  reasonably  available  to  the  inhabitants  of  the  community  or
country. Nonetheless, there are those that argue  that  trials  are  justified even  if  the  treatment
will not be immediately available after the trial is completed, it is a necessary step towards its
eventual availability.

In line with these arguments, the problem with the "best proven treatment" approach is that it
may  prevent  valuable  research  being  done,  as  treatments  and  services  will  not  be  readily
available  in  resource  -  poor  settings  and  may  not  be  provided  by  researchers  and  their
sponsors.

$+$(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)*(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:26)(cid:10)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)T"(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:24)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)U

Less argumentation is found in favor of always using the âbest proven treatmentâ against the
use  of  placebo  or  a  lower  standard  of  care  use  because  for  those  involved,  it  is  clearly  a
question of principles.  Non-accessibility or non-affordability of standard  treatment  should  not
be a reason to use placebo [28].  If the use of placebo causes irreversible avoidable damage, it
will never be ethically justified. To permit different levels of care in different clinical trials implies
an  ethical  double-standard,  opening  the  door  to  exploitation.  Same  care  for  all  attempts  to
provide maximal benefit to trial participants [6].

Drug-related research in developing countries, because of the availability of patients suffering
from  the  diseases,  makes  it  possible  to  do  the  trials  efficiently  and  rapidly.  And  that  makes
these areas more vulnerable to exploitation.

Even  when  a  host  country  agrees  to  allow  a  drug  trial,  substantial  ethical  difficulties  remain.
The basic rights of potential trial participants in some parts of Africa or other poor regions may
be so compromised that refusal to participate is not an option.  âEnrolling patients in a clinical
trial  will  always  look  attractive  if  there  is  no  treatment  to  offer,  no  matter  how  unethical  that
research may turn out to be." [29]

Those  that  defend  always  using  the  best-proven  therapy,  defend  that  some  things  are
fundamentally  wrong,  no  matter  how  good  their  consequences.    Dostoevsky,  in  The
Karamazov  Brothers,  illustrates  this  posing  the  following  dilemma:  if  the  edifice  of  human
destiny could be built just perfect (complete happiness, peace and contentment for everybody)
on top of an innocent child that must die in the process, who would honestly do it under these
conditions?  In this line of reasoning, advocating against the use of placebo, Kantâs ethics can
be put forward: we must always treat people as ends, never as means.

172

This group sees an important problem with the "highest attainable or best available treatment"
goal in that it may lead to a marked decline in care - there are no clear criteria for establishing
what level of treatment is acceptable or firm safeguards for applying it.  For example, there are
many placebo trials for âme tooâ drugs that use placebo just because its easier to prove that
they work against a placebo than to prove they are better that the existing similar ones.

Nevertheless, some scientists have a less radical attitude and argue that the placebo control
can  be  a  powerful  methodological  tool  that,  in  some  specific  cases,  provides  rigor  and
efficiency in clinical trials and should therefore not be systematically excluded.

As  proposed  by  Miller  [30],  the  use  of  placebo  could  be  exclusively  limited  to  initial  trials,  in
small-scale  trials,  and  to  test  the  efficacy  of  the  agents  tested.  In  other  cases,  as  for
comparison of known drugs, the use of placebo is not justifiable [30].

$+&(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:17)(cid:8)(cid:24)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:7)(cid:10)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:3)D(cid:10)(cid:24)(cid:9)(cid:21)(cid:3)(cid:16)

In an attempt to study some of these arguments in practice, a few cases of clinical trials have
been selected from the scientific literature:

â¢  Case 1: Lack of availability or use of placebo to simplify the result?

tetanus immunoglobulin in the management of tetanus.

$!*(cid:30)â*(cid:30)B(cid:8) â(cid:27)$(cid:8) * /*(cid:30)G (cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)&"(cid:8) %â(cid:27)$(cid:26)(cid:31)&"(cid:8) â&&(cid:26)#â(cid:28)(cid:30)$(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8) %(cid:30)#(cid:30)!.(cid:30)(cid:8) (cid:30)!(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:8) (cid:16)7(cid:23)(cid:8) !(cid:12) (cid:12)(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) (cid:22)(cid:5)(cid:3)
!(cid:27)(cid:28)%â(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)#â&&"(cid:8)(cid:26)%(cid:8)â(cid:8)*(cid:29)â(cid:31)(cid:8))%(cid:26)#(cid:30)$ %(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:31)!(cid:31)!#?!(cid:27)((cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)& (cid:31)/â%(cid:8)) (cid:27)#(cid:28) %(cid:30)(cid:12)(cid:8)(cid:10)(cid:1)(cid:6)2(cid:4)(cid:22)(cid:6);(cid:8)(cid:5)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:31)!&$
(cid:28)(cid:30)(cid:28)â(cid:27) *B(cid:8) (cid:22)(cid:5)(cid:3)(cid:8) â$(cid:31)!(cid:27)!*(cid:28)%â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8) *!((cid:27)!+!#â(cid:27)(cid:28)&"(cid:8) %(cid:30)(cid:28)â%$(cid:30)$(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) %â(cid:28)(cid:30)(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) )%(cid:26)(%(cid:30)**!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8) ,)(cid:8) W(cid:8) (cid:23)(cid:12)(cid:23)70B
%(cid:30)$ #(cid:30)$(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)$ %â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)(cid:29)(cid:26)*)!(cid:28)â&(cid:8),)(cid:8)W(cid:8)(cid:23)(cid:12)(cid:23)(cid:17)0(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:30)(cid:27)*!.(cid:30)(cid:8)#â%(cid:30)(cid:8) (cid:27)!(cid:28)(cid:8)*(cid:28)â"(cid:8),)(cid:8)W(cid:8)(cid:23)(cid:12)(cid:23)70B(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:30)(cid:30)$
+(cid:26)%(cid:8)(cid:28)%â#(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:26)*(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:31)!(cid:30)*(cid:8),)(cid:8)W(cid:8)(cid:23)(cid:12)(cid:23)(cid:13)0(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)$(cid:26)*(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)*(cid:30)$â(cid:28)!.(cid:30)*(cid:8)%(cid:30)G !%(cid:30)$(cid:8)+(cid:26)%(cid:8)#(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)%(cid:26)&(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)*)â*(cid:31)*
,)(cid:8)W(cid:8)(cid:23)(cid:12)(cid:23)(cid:17)0(cid:12)(cid:8)(cid:5)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:31)!&$(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:30)(cid:28)â(cid:27) *B(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:31)(cid:26)%(cid:28)â&!(cid:28)"(cid:8)%â(cid:28)(cid:30)*(cid:8)>(cid:30)%(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:16)(cid:23)X(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)(cid:13)(cid:23)X(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:28)%(cid:30)â(cid:28)(cid:30)$(cid:8)â(cid:27)$
#(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)%(cid:26)&(cid:8)(%(cid:26) )*B(cid:8)%(cid:30)*)(cid:30)#(cid:28)!.(cid:30)&"(cid:12)
(cid:15)(cid:11)(cid:2)(cid:15)(cid:4)2(cid:6)(cid:5)(cid:11)(cid:2);(cid:8)E(cid:30)(cid:8)* (((cid:30)*(cid:28)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)â(cid:28)(cid:8)(cid:22)(cid:5)(cid:3)(cid:8)!*(cid:8) *(cid:30)+ &(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:8)%(cid:30)$ #!(cid:27)((cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:31)(cid:26)%/!$!(cid:28)"B(cid:8))%(cid:26)(%(cid:30)**!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:26)+
$!*(cid:30)â*(cid:30)(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)(cid:31)(cid:26)%(cid:28)â&!(cid:28)"(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:8))â(cid:28)!(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)*(cid:8))%(cid:30)*(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)!(cid:27)((cid:8)>!(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:8)(cid:31)!&$(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:30)(cid:28)â(cid:27) *(cid:12)

The experimental research was conducted in a university-affiliated teaching hospital and ethical
clearance was obtained from the Ethics Committee of the research institution.

173

The experiments are aimed to assess the effectiveness of intrathecal injection of anti-tetanus
immunoglobulin  (TIG)  for  the  treatment  of  tetanus  infection  [31].  The  authors  concluded  that
TIG is  useful  in  reducing  the  morbidity,  progression of  disease  and  mortality  in  patients.  The
journal where results were published, The National Medical Journal of India, follows IMCJEâs
Uniform Requirement for publication.

In  this  case,  the  authors  have  based  their  experiments  on  precedent  published  results.  The
literature  survey  has  revealed  that  precedent  studies  had  methodological  problems  (missing
randomized  placebo-controlled  study)  and  contradictory  results  (demonstration  or  not  of  the
benefice  of  TIG).  For  these  reasons,  a  randomized  placebo-controlled  study  for  TIG  was
deemed  necessary  to  complete  the  work  already  done  in  the  field  of  TIG  and  reduction  of
progression of disease.

However, there was a routine treatment available, since intramuscular TIG injection was known
to be effective. True that intrathecal administration was supposed to work better since it does
not have to cross the blood-brain barrier and achieves higher levels in the cerebrospinal fluid.
Also true that previous studies were conflicting but it is not so clear that the attempt to resolve
these conflicts justifies that the  control  group of  patients  did  not  receive  any  treatment at  all.
Intramuscular administration had to be available if intrathecal was available. A previous study in
1982  had  already  attempted  something  similar  but  without  the  use  of  placebo  [32].  Results
were  not  clear  at  the  time  though  intrathecal  administration  seemed  more  effective.  It  is
obviously  much  more  difficult  to  extract  conclusions  when  you  are  testing  a  new  therapy
against an existing one than it is to compare it to a placebo. Without attempting to draw general
conclusions  from  this  particular  study,  it  has  to  be  kept  in  mind  that  there  is  a  risk  of  using
placebo  just because  it  simplifies  the  analysis.  Lack  of  availability  could  then  be  used  as  an
excuse.

â¢  Case 2: Best proven treatment is not given even if available

immunodeficiency  virus-infected  mothers:  Bangkok.  Bangkok  Collaborative  Perinatal
HIV Transmission Study Group.

.*(cid:8)7(cid:17)(cid:12)7X0(cid:8)/ (cid:28)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:8)â(cid:28)(cid:8)&â(cid:28)(cid:30)%(cid:8)â((cid:30)*C(cid:8)(cid:31)(cid:30)â(cid:27)(cid:8)>(cid:30)!((cid:29)(cid:28)B(cid:8)(cid:29)(cid:30)!((cid:29)(cid:28)B(cid:8)(cid:29)(cid:30)â$(cid:8)#!%# (cid:31)+(cid:30)%(cid:30)(cid:27)#(cid:30)B(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)(cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:20),Y0
â(cid:27)$(cid:8) (cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:25),Y0(cid:8) (cid:22)(cid:8) &"(cid:31))(cid:29)(cid:26)#"(cid:28)(cid:30)(cid:8) #(cid:26) (cid:27)(cid:28)*(cid:8) >(cid:30)%(cid:30)(cid:8) *!(cid:31)!&â%(cid:8) !(cid:27)(cid:8) /(cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:8) (%(cid:26) )*(cid:8) â(cid:28)(cid:8) â&&(cid:8) â((cid:30)*(cid:12)(cid:8) (cid:14)!.(cid:30)
 (cid:27)!(cid:27)+(cid:30)#(cid:28)(cid:30)$(cid:8)#(cid:29)!&$%(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)5(cid:21)(cid:9)(cid:8)(%(cid:26) )(cid:8)/ (cid:28)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:27)&"(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:30)(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8))&â#(cid:30)/(cid:26)(cid:8)(%(cid:26) )(cid:8)(cid:29)â$(cid:8)â(cid:8)+(cid:30)/%!&(cid:30)
#(cid:26)(cid:27). &*!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:12)(cid:8) (cid:2)(cid:26)(cid:8) (cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%(cid:8) *!((cid:27)*(cid:8) * (((cid:30)*(cid:28)!.(cid:30)(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) (cid:31)!(cid:28)(cid:26)#(cid:29)(cid:26)(cid:27)$%!â&(cid:8) $"*+ (cid:27)#(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8) â(cid:27)$(cid:8) (cid:27)(cid:26)(cid:8) (cid:28) (cid:31)(cid:26)%*
>(cid:30)%(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:26)/*(cid:30)%.(cid:30)$(cid:12)(cid:8)(cid:19)(cid:31)(cid:26)(cid:27)((cid:8)!(cid:27)+(cid:30)#(cid:28)(cid:30)$(cid:8)#(cid:29)!&$%(cid:30)(cid:27)B(cid:8)â(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:30)*(cid:28)!(cid:31)â(cid:28)(cid:30)$(cid:8)-(cid:16)X(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)5(cid:21)(cid:9)(cid:8)(%(cid:26) )(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)66X
!(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8))&â#(cid:30)/(cid:26)(cid:8)(%(cid:26) )(cid:8)* %.!.(cid:30)$(cid:8)+%(cid:30)(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)(cid:15)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:30)%*(cid:8)+(cid:26)%(cid:8)(cid:21)!*(cid:30)â*(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:15)(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)%(cid:26)&(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)3%(cid:30).(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8)#&â**
(cid:15)(cid:8) $!*(cid:30)â*(cid:30)(cid:8) $ %!(cid:27)((cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) (cid:17)(cid:25):(cid:31)(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:8) +(cid:26)&&(cid:26)>: )(cid:12)(cid:8) (cid:15)(cid:11)(cid:2)(cid:15)(cid:4)2(cid:6)(cid:5)(cid:11)(cid:2)(cid:6);(cid:8) (cid:2)(cid:26)(cid:8) *!((cid:27)!+!#â(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8) â$.(cid:30)%*(cid:30)
(cid:30).(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)*(cid:8) >(cid:30)%(cid:30)(cid:8) â**(cid:26)#!â(cid:28)(cid:30)$(cid:8) >!(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:8) *(cid:29)(cid:26)%(cid:28):#(cid:26) %*(cid:30)(cid:8) 5(cid:21)(cid:9)(cid:8) $ %!(cid:27)((cid:8) (cid:17)(cid:25)(cid:8) (cid:31)(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:29)*(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) +(cid:26)&&(cid:26)>: )(cid:8) !(cid:27)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)!*
)(cid:26)) &â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:12)

In the experimental studies conducted by  Chotpitayasunondh  et al,  the  researchers  begin  by
admitting  that  short-course  AZT  treatment  is  effective  and,  because  it  is  used  so  much  in
developing  countries,  they  aimed  to  assess  its  safety  for  the  new  born  [33].  The  authors
conclude that no significant adverse effects were associated with short-course ZDV after an 18-
month follow-up of the infants in this trial.

The  authors  have  used  placebo  as  standard  controlled  while  AZT  treatment  in  the  late-
pregnancy had been proven effective and it was relatively available, which is more important.
The arguments in favor of the use of placebo in previous clinical trials to develop a shorter, and
therefore cheaper, AZT do not apply here.  It is also contradictory the need to test for safety of
a treatment that has been used in industralised areas for many years (since 1994) to prevent
HIV perinatal transmission. The standard treatment in Western countries involves higher doses
and begins earlier in the pregnancy (the window of exposure of the fetus to AZT is longer) and
no irreversible side effects have been described so far [34, 35]. A trial to evaluate the safety of
the short-course treatment perhaps does not justify the use of placebo.

Similar  trials  using  placebo  arm  against the  short-course  AZT  treatment  to  measure  different
variables  like  AZT  concentration  in  the  cord  blood  [36],  cervicovaginal  RNA  levels  [37]  were
done  at  the  same  time  that  prevention  of  transmission  was  tested  but  it  is  interesting  in  this
case  the acceptance,  in the  abstract  itself,  of the  efficacy  of  the  treatment  known  before  the
trial.  In  February  1998,  all  use  of  placebo  in  AZT  trials  was  stopped,  after  publication  of  the
Thai study results [10].  As an interesting contrast, there was a clinical trial carried in the US
from 1995 to 1997 on abbreviated regimens of AZT, instead of the recommended long-course
regimen because of limited prenatal care. No placebo was used in this trial that suggested that
HIV transmission was reduced even with much shortened AZT treatments (intrapartum or in the
first 48 hours of life) [38].

The  results  of  this  experiment  have  been  published  in  Pediatrics  which  follows  IMCJEâs
Uniform  Requirement  for  publication.  As  a  general  trend,  Clarke  et  al  [39]  found  that  most
authors of articles published in medical journals do not discuss how they research compares
with other research on the same topic.  Results of a new trial are not placed in the context of
other relevant research. In a survey they have conducted between 1997 and 2001, there was
no  evidence  of  progress  in  the  proportion  of  reports  of  trials  published  in  general  medical
journals that discussed  the  new  results  within  the  context  of,  or  with  reference  to, up-to-date
systematic  reviews  of  relevant  evidence  from  other  controlled  trials.  However,  just  to
counterbalance this judgment, the following case is an example of the contrary, a clinical trial
developed and designed in the context of other trials and their results.

175

â¢  Case 3:  Design of the trial adapts to new data

F(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:11)(cid:10)(cid:21): Lancet 2002 Apr 6;359(9313):1178-86
(cid:1)(cid:14)(cid:13)(cid:21)(cid:3):  Efficacy  of  three  short-course  regimens  of  zidovudine  and  lamivudine  in
preventing early and late transmission of HIV-1 from mother to child in Tanzania, South
Africa, and Uganda (Petra study): a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.
-(cid:6)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:16): The Petra Study Team.

(cid:17)7(cid:12)(cid:13)X(cid:8) +(cid:26)%(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) )&â#(cid:30)/(cid:26)(cid:8) (%(cid:26) )(cid:12)(cid:8) (cid:10)(cid:30)*)(cid:30)#(cid:28)!.(cid:30)(cid:8) %(cid:30)&â(cid:28)!.(cid:30)(cid:8) %!*?*(cid:8) +(cid:26)%(cid:8) (cid:7)(cid:5)(cid:9):(cid:17)(cid:8) (cid:28)%â(cid:27)*(cid:31)!**!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8) !(cid:27)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)

(cid:23)(cid:12)1(cid:20)0B(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8) (cid:23)(cid:12)1(cid:13)(cid:8) ,(cid:23)(cid:12)-(cid:16):(cid:17)(cid:12)(cid:20)(cid:23)0(cid:12)(cid:8) (cid:14)(cid:26)%(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) #(cid:26)(cid:31)/!(cid:27)(cid:30)$(cid:8) (cid:30)(cid:27)$)(cid:26)!(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) (cid:7)(cid:5)(cid:9):(cid:17)(cid:8) !(cid:27)+(cid:30)#(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8) â(cid:27)$(cid:8) !(cid:27)+â(cid:27)(cid:28)
