â(cid:27)â&"*!*B(cid:8) (cid:7)(cid:5)(cid:9):(cid:17)(cid:8) !(cid:27)+(cid:30)#(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8) %â(cid:28)(cid:30)*(cid:8) â(cid:28)(cid:8) (cid:31)(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:8) (cid:17)(cid:25)(cid:8) >(cid:30)%(cid:30)(cid:8) (cid:17)7X(cid:8) ,17X(cid:8) (cid:15)(cid:5)(cid:8) 1:(cid:16)(cid:13)0B(cid:8) (cid:17)(cid:25)X(cid:8) ,(cid:17)(cid:16):(cid:16)-0B
(cid:16)(cid:23)X(cid:8),(cid:17)(cid:13):(cid:13)(cid:23)0(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8)(cid:16)(cid:16)X(cid:8),(cid:17)-:(cid:13)(cid:23)0B(cid:8)%(cid:30)*)(cid:30)#(cid:28)!.(cid:30)&"(cid:12)(cid:8)(cid:5)(cid:2)(cid:22)(cid:1)(cid:10)3(cid:10)(cid:1)(cid:22)(cid:19)(cid:22)(cid:5)(cid:11)(cid:2);(cid:8) (cid:19)&(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:26) ((cid:29)(cid:8)â(cid:28)(cid:8) >(cid:30)(cid:30)?(cid:8) -
â+(cid:28)(cid:30)%(cid:8)/!%(cid:28)(cid:29)B(cid:8)%(cid:30)(!(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:27)*(cid:8)(cid:19)(cid:8)â(cid:27)$(cid:8) 8(cid:8) >(cid:30)%(cid:30)(cid:8) (cid:30)++(cid:30)#(cid:28)!.(cid:30)(cid:8) !(cid:27)(cid:8) %(cid:30)$ #!(cid:27)((cid:8) (cid:7)(cid:5)(cid:9):(cid:17)(cid:8) (cid:28)%â(cid:27)*(cid:31)!**!(cid:26)(cid:27)B(cid:8) /(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:30)+!(cid:28)*
(cid:29)â.(cid:30)(cid:8)$!(cid:31)!(cid:27)!*(cid:29)(cid:30)$(cid:8)#(cid:26)(cid:27)*!$(cid:30)%â/&"(cid:8)â+(cid:28)(cid:30)%(cid:8)(cid:17)(cid:25)(cid:8)(cid:31)(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:29)*(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)+(cid:26)&&(cid:26)>: )(cid:12)(cid:8)(cid:5)(cid:27)(cid:28)%(cid:26)$ #(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)*(cid:29)(cid:26)%(cid:28):#(cid:26) %*(cid:30)
%(cid:30)(!(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:27)*(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8))%(cid:30).(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:8)(cid:31)(cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%:(cid:28)(cid:26):#(cid:29)!&$(cid:8)(cid:28)%â(cid:27)*(cid:31)!**!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:5)(cid:9):(cid:17)(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:8)&(cid:30)**:$(cid:30).(cid:30)&(cid:26))(cid:30)$(cid:8)#(cid:26) (cid:27)(cid:28)%!(cid:30)*
*(cid:29)(cid:26) &$(cid:8) /(cid:30)(cid:8) â##(cid:26)(cid:31))â(cid:27)!(cid:30)$(cid:8) /"(cid:8) !(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:30)%.(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)*(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8) (cid:31)!(cid:27)!(cid:31)!*(cid:30)(cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) %!*?(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) * /*(cid:30)G (cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)
(cid:28)%â(cid:27)*(cid:31)!**!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8).!â(cid:8)/%(cid:30)â*(cid:28)+(cid:30)(cid:30)$!(cid:27)((cid:12)

This trial was conducted by the Petra Study Team [40] to assess the efficacy of short-course
regimens peripartum HIV-1 transmission from mother to child, conducted between June 1996
and January 2000.  In this case, the patients were divided first into 4 study groups: A, AZT plus
lamivudine during gestation, followed by oral intrapartum and postpartum dosing; B, regimen A
without the prepartum component; C, intrapartum zidovudine and lamivudine only; or placebo.
From  February  1998  onward,  after  publication  of  the  Thai  study  results,  women  were  not
randomised  to  a  placebo  group,  only  the  other  3  active  treatment  groups.  The  authors
concluded that regime A and B are effective in reducing HIV-1 transmission the first 6 months,
but benefits diminished considerable after an 18-month follow-up.

176

This clinical design is concordant with the idea that if no treatment is available, placebo should
be used, once the cheaper, more available, treatment is proven effective, there is no excuse to
keep using placebo so they dropped it.

&+(cid:1) (cid:1)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:24)(cid:9)(cid:10)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:16)#(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:16)(cid:15)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:26)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:6)"(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:16)

&+(cid:30)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4))(cid:6)"(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:16)

The  concern  raised  by  the  crisis  of  1997,  and  the  publication  of  several  editorials  in  major
medical  journals  [6],  induced  a  strong  reaction  at  international  level.  Looking  for  a  possible
impact of this crisis, leaded by the âcontroversy machineâ, a search of the number of scientific
publication in medical journals that have been published before and after the 1997 debate has
been  carried  out.  The  search  has  focused  on  AIDS  clinical  trials  in  Africa  and  world-wild.
Indeed,  the  problem  of  access  to  medicine  in  AIDS  treatment  is  crucial  in  Africa  where  just
0.1%  of  the 28.5  million  of  people  leaving  with  HIV/AIDS  in  Africa  have  access  to  HIV/AIDS
drugs [41].

The search was done on Medline database24 in the period 1992-2001, limited to clinical trials in
humans and using a combination of  the terms  âplaceboâ,  âAIDSâ,  âHIVâ,  âAfricaâ,  to  show the
trends overtime  in  scientific  publication,  looking  for  the  impacts  of  the  HIV  scandal.  With  the
Medline search, we have sorted the total amount of publications related to the subject for the
period 1992-2001 and then estimated the percentage of publication per year. In each search,
values for year 2002 (Jan. â June) were eliminated.

In a first search, we have compared the number of publication for experiments conducted with
placebo  to  experiments  conducted  with  placebo  for  HIV/AIDS  clinical  trials.  The  number  of
scientific publications related to experiments conducted on human clinical trials with the use of
placebo worldwide is extremely constant over the last 10 years, with a range of 2700 â 3302
publications  per  year  (Figure  1).  If  the  research  is  limited  to  experiments  conducted  with
placebo for AIDS treatment, the number of publications shows an effect of the HIV scandal is
not constant.  There is an increased number of publications between 1997 â  1999 and  clear
decline  in  1999  (Figure  1).  The  lag  phase  between  the  scandal  (year  1997)  and  the  drop  in
publication number (year 1999) is a reflection of the time it takes to finish the trials and publish
the  results.  The  number  of  publication  in  medical  journals  for  research  conducted  on  AIDS
treatment without specifying the use or not of placebo, has been used as a control (data not
shown),  and  does  not  present  such  drastic  drop  since  1999.  There  is  an  obvious
stimulus/response effect as seen in the graph (Figure 1).

24  PubMed,  a  service  of  the  National  Library  of  Medicine,  provides  access  to  over  11  million
MEDLINE  citations  back  to  the  mid-1960âs.    The  database  covers  the  fields  of  medicine,  nursing,
dentistry,  veterinary  medicine, the  health  care  system,  and  the  pre-clinical  sciences  in  around  30,000
scientific journals worldwide.

177

!(cid:14)(cid:22)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:30)8(cid:4)(cid:5)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:21)(cid:6)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:16)(cid:15)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:26)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:6)"(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:21)(cid:10)(cid:15)(cid:3)"(cid:8)

In a second search, we have compared the number of publications related to clinical trials with
placebo for HIV purpose in Africa and world-wide. Even if there was a marked decline following
the  HIV  scandal,  there  is  a  clear  trend  of  increasing  number  of  trials  conducted  in  Africa.
Nowadays,  Africa  is  the  continent  with  the  highest  proportion  of  population  affected  by  AIDS
and many of the experimental human clinical trials are therefore conducted there. As shown in
Figure 2, the proportion of experiments conducted in Africa increased in 1998 onwards.

(cid:12)(cid:30)(cid:23)(cid:25)(cid:20)(cid:22)(cid:23)(cid:26)(cid:23)(cid:30)(cid:1)(cid:29)(cid:24))!(cid:23)(cid:30)#(cid:22)(cid:23)(cid:27)(cid:20)(cid:21)(cid:1) (cid:24)( #(cid:20)*(cid:30)!(cid:23)(cid:20)(cid:23)(cid:30)#!(cid:1)(cid:22)(cid:28)(cid:23)#!(cid:21)*(cid:29)!#(cid:30)(cid:25))(cid:27)*(cid:19)(cid:11)+

,(cid:25)#(cid:28)(cid:21)

!(cid:14)(cid:22)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:4)$8(cid:4)(cid:23)(cid:8)(cid:24)(cid:9)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:16)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:6)"(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4)-(cid:26)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:4)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:16)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:20)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:21)(cid:18)

178

Though  methodologically  imperfect  and  incomplete,  this  bibliographical  search  is  meant  to
show the trend, a general tendency to carry more and more trials in less developed countries.
It can be argued that these areas are also more afflicted by the disease but it is also true that
much of the data is of use in industrialized countries.

One  recent  decision  might  influence  this  general  tendency  to  carry  more  trials  in  less
developed  countries  as  they  will  offer  patients  more  opportunities  for  treatment.  The  World
Health  Organization  has  formally  launched  in  July  2002  new  international  guidelines  for  the
treatment  of  AIDS  in  resource-poor  settings  [42].  From  now,  highly  complex  anti-retroviral
therapy  (ARV)  can  be  used  in  settings  that  donât  have  highly  trained  medical  staff  and
sophisticated  laboratories.  This  major  simplification  in  the  ARV  treatment,  combined  with  the
falling costs of medicine, will allow million of people to benefit from the HIV/AIDS treatment.

&+$(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:1)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:6)"(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)"(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:16)

An important concern about the reliability of scientific publication of results from clinical trials is
precisely  the  fact  that  many  of  them  are  not  published.  This  phenomenon,  known  as  the
âpublication biasâ gives a distorted picture for both doctors and patients.

Control  of  publication  and  research  outcome  might  be  influenced  by  publishing  in  non-peer-
reviewed  material  as  supplement  in  a  respected  journal  [43].  Delays  in  the  publication  of
unfavorable results are common, and it is speculated that the results of many clinical trials are
never published at all [44].  Dr Terry Klassen, chair of a department of pediatrics, estimates that
up  to  40  per  cent  of  studies  conducted  on  children  are  not  published25.    Klassen  et  al  [45]
calculated that only 59.1% of articles presented at a major pediatric scientific meeting (Society
for Pediatric Research) were subsequently published as full-length articles. This indicated that
the percentage of publication bias is not negligible.

One  study  of  university-industry  research  centres  conducted  in  the  United  States  found  that
35% of signed agreements allowed  the  sponsors  to  delete  information  from  publication,  53%
allowed delay of publication and 30 % allowed both  [46].    This  one  major  flaw,  together  with
conflict  of  interest  on  the  part  of  investigator  and  inappropriate  involvement  of  research
sponsors, currently imperils the reliability of scientific literature on clinical trials [47].

&+&(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:4)(cid:5)(cid:18)(cid:14)(cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:22)(cid:6)(cid:14)(cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:28)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:9)(cid:10)(cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:16)(cid:14)(cid:13)(cid:6)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:16)

In  the  view  of  the  British  Medical  Research  Council  it  is  not  enough  to  ensure  that  all
investigation is carried out in an ethical manner: this must also be made unmistakably clear in
the publication.  This implies editorial responsibility in addition to the investigatorâs. Article 27 of
the  Declaration  is  very  clear  to  this  respect:  8(cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:8) â (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:26)%*(cid:8) â(cid:27)$(cid:8) ) /&!*(cid:29)(cid:30)%*(cid:8) (cid:29)â.(cid:30)(cid:8) (cid:30)(cid:28)(cid:29)!#â&
(cid:26)/&!(â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)*(cid:12)(cid:8)(cid:8)(cid:8)(cid:5)(cid:27)(cid:8)) /&!#â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)%(cid:30)* &(cid:28)*(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)%(cid:30)*(cid:30)â%#(cid:29)B(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)!(cid:27).(cid:30)*(cid:28)!(â(cid:28)(cid:26)%*(cid:8)â%(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:26)/&!((cid:30)$(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8))%(cid:30)*(cid:30)%.(cid:30)
(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) â## %â#"(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) (cid:8) (cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8) %(cid:30)* &(cid:28)*(cid:12)(cid:8) (cid:8) (cid:2)(cid:30)(â(cid:28)!.(cid:30)(cid:8) â*(cid:8) >(cid:30)&&(cid:8) â*(cid:8) )(cid:26)*!(cid:28)!.(cid:30)(cid:8) %(cid:30)* &(cid:28)*(cid:8) *(cid:29)(cid:26) &$(cid:8) /(cid:30)(cid:8) ) /&!*(cid:29)(cid:30)$(cid:8) (cid:26)%
(cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)%>!*(cid:30)(cid:8)) /&!#&"(cid:8)â.â!&â/&(cid:30)(cid:12)

25 CTVNEWS 28 May 2002 Available at http://www.CTVNEWS.com

179

                                                     
(cid:6)(cid:26) %#(cid:30)*(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) + (cid:27)$!(cid:27)(B(cid:8) !(cid:27)*(cid:28)!(cid:28) (cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)â&(cid:8) â++!&!â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)*(cid:8) â(cid:27)$(cid:8) â(cid:27)"(cid:8) )(cid:26)**!/&(cid:30)(cid:8) #(cid:26)(cid:27)+&!#(cid:28)*(cid:8) (cid:26)+(cid:8) !(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:30)%(cid:30)*(cid:28)(cid:8) *(cid:29)(cid:26) &$(cid:8) /(cid:30)
$(cid:30)#&â%(cid:30)$(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)) /&!#â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:12)(cid:8)(cid:8)(cid:10)(cid:30))(cid:26)%(cid:28)*(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)(cid:30)H)(cid:30)%!(cid:31)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:8)!(cid:27) â##(cid:26)%$â(cid:27)#(cid:30)(cid:8)>!(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8))%!(cid:27)#!)&(cid:30)*
&â!$(cid:8)$(cid:26)>(cid:27)(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)!*(cid:8)(cid:21)(cid:30)#&â%â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8)*(cid:29)(cid:26) &$(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:26)(cid:28)(cid:8)/(cid:30)(cid:8)â##(cid:30))(cid:28)(cid:30)$(cid:8)+(cid:26)%(cid:8)) /&!#â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:12)

Even  if  scientifically  very  valuable,  data  that  has  been  obtained  improperly  should  not  be
published,  according  to  Beecher  [48],  because  failure  to  obtain  publication  will  discourage
unethical  experimentation.  If  suppression  of  the  data  (by  no  publishing  it)  would  constitute  a
loss to medicine, this loss would be less important than the moral loss if it were to be published.
On  the  other  hand,  some  have  critizised  this  clause  of  the  Declaration  because  it  obliges  to
publish pilot studies, which are preliminary and could be used by competitors [27]. On the other
hand, a group of thirteen leading medical journals have criticized, in September 2001, the drug
industry  saying  that  the  industryâs  financial  interest  are  jeopardizing  the  objectivity  of  clinical
research. The journals have agreed not to review or publish articles based on studies that are
conducted under conditions that allow drug company to sole control of the data. They will ask
authors  to  sign  a  statement  saying  they  have  full  responsibility  for  the  trialâs  conduct,  data
access and decision for publishing the study [49].

In 2002, Yank and Rennie [50] compared the clinical trials published before and after 1997 in 5
international  journals  (Annals  of  Internal  Medicine,  British  Medical  Journal,  Journal  of  the
American  Medical Association,  The  Lancet  and  The  New  England  Journal  of  Medicine).  The
results showed that 30% of articles published before 1997 did not report informed consent and
another  30%  did  not  report  ethics  committee  approval.  Since  1997,  these  major  medical
journals  have  improved  their  reporting  on  informed  consent  and  ethics  committee  approval.
Indeed, the percentage of articles without informed consent decreased from 28% (between July
1995-  Dec  1996)  to  18%  (between  Jan  1998  -  June  1999),  and  the  percentage  of  articles
without mention of ethic committee approval dropped from 31% before 1997 to 18% after 1997.
The authors concluded that reference to both informed consent and ethic committee approval
is increasing but still, 9% of studies report neither. This result is in line with the outcome of prior
studies.  Ruiz-Canela  et  al.  [51]  found  no  mention  of  informed  consent  in  20%  and  ethical
approval in 30% and Matot et al [52] reported that 40% of critical care articles from 1994 lacked
a statement on informed consent, and 40% had no statement on ethical review.

Presented below is an overview of the requirements defined by general medical journals from
both developed and less developed countries.

(cid:25)(cid:13)(cid:20)(cid:13)().(cid:6))*((cid:13)(cid:13)4(cid:13)(cid:20)(cid:15)(cid:6)(cid:17)((cid:16)4(cid:6)(cid:15)(cid:12)(cid:13)(cid:6)(cid:30)(cid:20)(cid:15)(cid:13)((cid:20))(cid:15)(cid:19)(cid:16)(cid:20)).(cid:6)(cid:9)(cid:16)44(cid:19)(cid:15)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:13)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:17)(cid:6)&(cid:13)/(cid:19)+).(cid:6)@(cid:16)â((cid:20)).(cid:6)(cid:5)/(cid:19)(cid:15)(cid:16)(0(cid:6)1(cid:30)(cid:9)&@(cid:5)2

In  1978,  a  small  group  of  editors  of  general  medical  journals  decided  to  establish
guidelines for the format of manuscripts submitted to their journals. This initial group,
known  as  the  Vancouver  Group,  expanded  and  evolved  into  the  International
Committee of Medical Journal Editors (ICMJE). The committee has produced multiple
editions  of  the  Uniform  Requirements  for  Manuscripts  Submitted  to  Biomedical
Journals  [53].  Over  the  years,  issues  have  arisen  that  go  beyond  manuscript
preparation.  Some  of  these  issues  are  now  covered  in  the  Uniform  Requirements,
others  are  addressed  in  separate  statements.  The  entire  Uniform  Requirement
document was revised in 1997. Sections were updated in May 1999 and May 2000. A
major revision is scheduled for 2002.

180

In  the  section  âRequirements  for  Submission  of  Manuscriptsâ(cid:0)(cid:1),  a  special  chapter  is
dedicated to ethics of experiments done on human subjects. In the text, it is stipulated
that if the authors are reporting experiments on human subjects, they should indicate
whether the procedures followed were in accordance with the ethical standards of the
responsible  committee  on  human  experimentation  (institutional  or  regional)  and  with
the  Helsinki  Declaration.  It  is  forbidden  to  use  patientsâ  names,  initials,  or  hospital
numbers, in text or illustrative material.

In  the  separate  statement  dedicated  to  âPublication  Ethics:  Sponsorship,  Authorship  and
Accountabilityâ27 [54], the editors of general medical journals recognised that the publication of
clinical  research  findings  in  respected  peer-reviewed  journals  is  the  basis  for  most  treatment
decision. In this respect, the current intellectual environment in which some clinical research is
conceived, study participants are recruited, and data analysed and reported may threaten this
objective and should be handled carefully.

ICMJE stipulates that F*#!(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)!*(cid:28)*(cid:8)(cid:29)â.(cid:30)(cid:8)â(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:30)(cid:28)(cid:29)!#â&(cid:8)(cid:26)/&!(â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:8)* /(cid:31)!(cid:28)(cid:8)#%(cid:30)$!(cid:28)â/&(cid:30)(cid:8)%(cid:30)*(cid:30)â%#(cid:29)(cid:8)%(cid:30)* &(cid:28)*
+(cid:26)%(cid:8) ) /&!#â(cid:28)!(cid:26)(cid:27)â.    This  comment  is  more  directly  related  to  the  conflict  of  interest  when  the
author  (or  authorâs  institution),  reviewer,  or  editor  has  financial  or  personal  relationships  that
influence his decisions.

More than 500 journals have signed the agreement, the majority from industrialized countries
(e.g.  Annals  of  Internal  Medicine,  British  Medical  Journal,  Canadian  Medical  Association
Journal, JAMA, New Zealand Medical Journal, The Lancet, The Medical Journal of Australia,
Western Journal of Medicine) but also many journals from less developed countries (Annals of
Tropical  Paedriatrics,  Bangladesh  Paediatrics,  Central  African  Journal  of  Medicine,  Nigerian
Medical  Journal,  Revista  Cubana  de  Investigaciones  Biomedicas,  Tropical  Doctor).  A  non-
exhaustive  list  of  journals  co-signatory  of  the  Uniform  Requirements  is  available  on  the
Internet28.

In  addition  to  the  adhesion  to  the  Uniform  Requirements  as  defined  by  the  ICMJE,  many
journals have also a specific section in the Instruction for Authors, or In formation for Authors,
or  with  an  ethic  committee  where they  mentioned  specifically  the  importance  that the  journal
gives to the ethical aspect. There are a wide variety of actions taken by various journals. Some
illustrative examples are presented in the Annex (though not an exhaustive list).

 +(cid:1) (cid:23)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:16)

Looking  at  the  historical  developments  that  have  shaped  the  ethical  guidelines  of  medical
research on human subjects, it can be perceived that the trend has always been to respond to
social controversy sparked by an scandal, or what some considered to be a scandal.

26 Available at http://www.icmje.org/index.html
27 Available at http://www.icmje.org/sponsor.htm
28 http://www.icmje.org/jrnlist.html

181

                                                     
This  reactive  attitude  of  the  international  fora  could  perhaps  be  more    proactive.    Instead  of
trying to respond to failures switching a social âcontroversy machineâ in gear, an effort should
be made to prevent them in the future.

In the discussion of using the best proven versus the best available treatment when conducting
a clinical trial is difficult to achieve a consensus.  Those who defend same treatment for all do it
from  an  ethical  perspective  which  differs  greatly  from  those  who  defend  the  utilitarian  and
pragmatic  view  of  designing  the  clinical  trials  using  the  available  means  in  the  host  country
(with  the  idea  that  this  will  be  of  better  use  to  that  country).    It  is  a  question  of  accepting  a
unique  standard  of  care  for  industrialised  and  developing  countries  without  differences  or  to
make  a distinction  because  of  their  different  contexts.  Part  of  the  problem  is  that  the  normal
âstandard  of  careâ  against  which  to  test  a  new  drug  has  not  been  formally  and  adequately
defined  [24].    It  has  been  incorrectly  assumed,  according  to  Benatar  and  Singer,  that  the
standard  set  by  the  developed  countries  can  be  considered  the  norm.  What  these  authors
propose is a list of elements for consideration in redefining "standard of care"[55]:

â¢  Respect for the dignity of all subjects,
â¢  Doing  what  is  in  the  best  interests  of  the  subjects  that  is,  researching  those

diseases that commonly afflict them,

â¢  Aiming  for  a  distribution  of  risks  and  benefits  that  takes  into  consideration  the
potential magnitude of benefit to sponsors (to ensure that "research sweat shops"
do not become the norm in a globalizing world),

â¢  Obtaining meaningful informed consent in the subjects' home tongue and with an

understanding of their world view or value system,

â¢  Only  undertaking  research  that  will  be  of  benefit  to  the  community  being

researched,

â¢  Translating research findings into components of accessible care in the community

being researched,

â¢  Avoiding conflicts of interest and exploitation.

A similar package of factors to take into account to agree on the standard of care to be used on
a  given  trial  and  to  be  agreed  by  a  dialogue  between  sponsor  country,  host  country  and
community representatives is provided by the UNAIDS Guidance Document29:

1.  level of care and treatment available in sponsor country,
2.  highest level of care available in the host country,
3.  highest level of treatment available in the host country,
4.  availability  of  infrastructure  to  provide  care  and  treatment  in  the  context  of  the

research,

5.  potential duration and sustainability of care and treatment for the trial participant.

UNAIDS sets the ideal standard as the âbest proven treatmentâ and the minimum standard of
the âhighest level of care attainable in the host countryâ.

Perhaps somewhere along this line lies the best way to achieve a consensus through dialogue
between all stakeholders on a case by case situation, before any trial is started.

29 See footnote number 6

182

                                                     
Another  proposal  to  improve  assessment  of  ethics  in  research  in  clinical  trials  in  developing
countries comes from Emanuel et al [56].  They draw from the main codes, declarations, and
other documents  relevant  to  research  with  human  subjects  and  propose  7  requirements  that
systematically  elucidate  a  coherent  framework  for  evaluating  the  ethics  of  clinical  research
studies.  They  maintain  that  fulfilling  all  7  requirements  is  necessary  and  sufficient  to  make
clinical  research  ethical  and  that  these  requirements  are  universal,  although  they  must  be
adapted  to  the  health,  economic,  cultural,  and  technological  conditions  in  which  clinical
research is conducted.  These requirements are the following:

(1)  value-enhancements of health or knowledge must be derived from the research,
(2)  scientific validity-the research must be methodologically rigorous,
(3)  fair  subject  selection-scientific  objectives,  not  vulnerability  or  privilege,  and  the
potential  for  and  distribution  of  risks  and  benefits,  should  determine  communities
selected as study sites and the inclusion criteria for individual subjects,

(4)  favorable  risk-benefit  ratio-within  the  context  of  standard  clinical  practice  and  the
research  protocol,  risks  must  be  minimized,  potential  benefits  enhanced,  and  the
potential benefits  to  individuals  and  knowledge  gained  for  society  must  outweigh  the
risks,

(5)  independent  review-unaffiliated  individuals  must  review  the  research  and  approve,

amend, or terminate it,

(6)  informed consent-individuals should be informed about the research and provide their

voluntary consent,

(7)  respect  for  enrolled  subjects-subjects  should  have  their  privacy  protected,  the

opportunity to withdraw, and their well-being monitored.

This goes back to the review on a case by case bases. Trials that are going to take place in
developing countries are influenced by important factors that include severe global inequality in
the  distribution  of  health  and  health  resources.    These  inequalities  make  every  trial  different
though a group of universal rules, as proposed by these authors, could eventually unify them
from  an  ethical  point  of  view.    The  Declaration  aims  exactly  to  do  this,  the  fact  that
disagreements have made its role unclear is something to keep into consideration.  Much of the
discussion  was  sparked  by  the  HIV  perinatal  transmission  trials  in  1997  and  still  no  full
agreement has been achieved.

Miller et al [57] have employed this systematic ethical framework for the analysis of industry-
sponsored clinical trials. They concluded that ethical framework as defined offers valuable tool
for members of institutional review board in reviewing clinical research protocols and for peer
reviewers and journal editors reviewing manuscripts describing the results of clinical trials. The
use  of  placebo  is  in  the  heart  of  the  evaluation  and  the  author  recommended  that  both
sponsors, investigators and authors should justify systematically the use of placebo.

The recent initiative undertaken by the European Commission under the European-Developing
Countries Clinical Trials Programme (EDCTP)30 might be an occasion to draw and implement
most adequate guidelines for clinical trials in developing countries.

from 

30 EDCTP This project has received for the first phase, which is expected to last 12 months, a packet of a  (cid:1)(cid:2)(cid:3)
the  Hospital  Clinic  of  Barcelona.
million  grant 
http://europa.eu.int/comm/research/info/conferences/edctp/edctpini_en.html
Reference  to  communication  from  the  European  Commission  to  the  council  and  the  European  Parliament
COM(2001) 96 final

the  European  Commission  and 

led  by 

is 

183

                                                     
The EDCTP goals are to increase the effectiveness of Europeâs investment in clinical trials for
interventions  against  HIV/AIDS,  tuberculosis  and  malaria.  In  this  programme,  EDCTP
associated clinical trial sites will be established and will have the capacity to design, conduct
and  analysis  clinical  trials  (protocols  accepted  by  regulatory  authorities  for  registration  and
licensure)  related  to  HIV  and/or  tuberculosis  and/or  malaria.  The  EDCTP  engages  to  ensure
transparent and accountability of its decision making progress by clear independent review of
proposals and ethical review and compliance with regulatory requirements.

Regarding publication of results from clinical trials, it is clear that those journals that present the
most  rigid  ethical  requirements  are  the  ones  that  present  some  of  the  most  valuable
interventions.    Strict  ethical  constraints  in  publication  do  not  seem  to  hinder  research  but  to
improve  it  and  so  some  researchers  are  very  much  defending  rigorous  rules.  On  the  other
hand,  there  are  those  who  see  a  risk  of  forcing  research  to  go  unpublished  if  ethical
requirements become too strict. There is already strong publication bias in the field of results of
clinical trials.  The possibility that editors of medical journals enhance their requirements might
have negative consequences on the publication of clinical trialsâ results.

There was an interesting impact on scientific literature from the HIV trials. Authors of scientific
reports  submitted  to  medical  journal  are  more  likely  to  include  informed  consent  and  ethics
committee approval in their report than they were before 1997. Still, many journals do not have
a special section in their recommendations to authors specifically focused on ethics. Journals
should  make  a  clear  and  systematic  mention  of  the  minimum  ethical  requirements  in  their
instructions  for  authors.    With  explicit  requirement  that  all  articles  describe  informed  consent
and an ethics committee approval or if not, why they are not mentioned.

In general, results of the clinical trials are rarely related to precedent results of similar studies
published in medical journal. Clarke et al [39] have recently observed that between 1997 and
2001, there is no evidence of progress in the proportion of reports of trials published in general
medical journals that discussed the new results within the context of, or with reference to, up-
to-date systematic reviews of relevant evidence from other controlled trials.

Finally, it has been detected that many clinical trials go unpublished, which makes assuring full
ethical  behavior  more  difficult  because  these  trials  escape  scrutiny  under  publication
guidelines.

(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:5)(cid:6)(cid:2)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:1)(cid:9)(cid:5)(cid:10)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:12)(cid:12)(cid:11)(cid:5)(cid:8)

(cid:17)(cid:23)(cid:26)(cid:25)(cid:1)(cid:12)(cid:30)(cid:23)(cid:25)(cid:20)(cid:30)(cid:25)(cid:21)â(cid:1)(cid:11)(cid:20)(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:28)(#(cid:22)(cid:23)(cid:27)(cid:20)(cid:1)#(cid:20)$(cid:1)(cid:9)(cid:27)(((cid:24)(cid:20)(cid:23)(cid:30)#(cid:22)(cid:23)(cid:27)(cid:20)(cid:1)(cid:14)(cid:25)(cid:30) (cid:20)(cid:27)!(cid:27)"(cid:23)(cid:25)(cid:21)

*(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:7)#(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:8)(cid:9)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:16)

(cid:9)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:9)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:5)(cid:6)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:9)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:12)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:9)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:5)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:16)

(cid:25)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:8)"(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:4)$%%$

(cid:30)+(cid:1) ,(cid:10)(cid:15)A(cid:22)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:18)

Following the IPTS report on âThe ethical controversy over the use of placebo in clinical trials in
developing countries: impact on international research guidelines and scientific literatureâ, the
European Group on Ethics in Science and New Technologies requested IPTS to collect more
specific  information  on  the  activities  of  the  pharmaceutical  industries  in  developing  countries
and their investment in clinical trials. The information collected is presented in this report.

$+(cid:1) *(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:8)(cid:18)(cid:6)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)

Randomised controlled clinical trials have become the standard for answering clinical questions
in drug development and, in recent years, there has been a rapid growth in their number.
Clinical trials (phases I to IV31) assess the suitability of new medicines or new uses for existing
ones and are the longest and most expensive part of developing a medicinal product.  Due in
part to these very high costs, there has been two major shifts in how those trials are funded
(and carried out) and where. The first notable shift, from government to industry-funded, has
contributed to the second.  Trials are moving away from academic centres to contract for-profit
research centres located in geographical areas different to the ones with longer history of
biomedical research.

Some  see  these  trends  as  dangerous  because  they  claim  that  it  gives  industry  excessive
control over the trials.  According to this critical group, it might affect the protection of human
subjects  that  take  part  in  the  trials  and  potentially  affect  the  ethics  of  the  overall  process
(Reynolds  2001).  Several  problems  have  already been  identified  with  industry-funded  clinical
trials.  In  May 1999,  the  (cid:2)(cid:30)>(cid:8) 4(cid:26)%?(cid:8) (cid:22)!(cid:31)(cid:30)*  raised  the  problems  of  paying  physicians  to  recruit
patients  for  clinical  trials,  disclosure  of  financial  interest  of  physician-investigators  and
compensation of patients for participation in clinical trials (Eichenwald 1999).

31 Phase I involves health volunteers (less than 50 study subjects/drug). Phase II involves patients and aims to
provide  a  proof  of  concept  (around  100  study  subjects/drug).  Phase  III  involves  patients  for  testing  safety  and
efficacy  of  the  drug  (1000  to  10.000  study  subjects/drug).  Phase  IV  involves  patient  for  safety  and  broader
indication tests (30.000 to 50.000 study subjects/drug). The first three phases constitute the clinical development
and take from 5 to 10 years.

191

                                                     
Numerous  problems  with  the  reporting  of  clinical  trials  results  have  also  been  identified  in
recent  years,  including  suppression,  non  objective  interpretation  or  underreporting  of  results
that  did  not  support  the  new  drug  and  a  more  systematic  use  of  placebo  as  control  for
industry-funded clinical trials (Djulbegovic 2001; Miller and Shorr 2002).

Pharmaceutical industry R&D is growing and becoming a global undertaking. Although figures
of  the  pharmaceutical  industry  as  a  whole are  not  currently  available,  it  is  evident  that  many
companies  are  increasing  their  number  of  foreign  clinical  trials.  These  trials  are  being
conducted more and more often in countries with less experience in research, which may offer
less  guarantees  of  proper  handling  of  regulatory  and
ethical issues (Kass and Hyder 2001; Rehnquist 2001).

&+(cid:1) â(cid:8)(cid:20)(cid:4)(cid:24)(cid:6)(cid:15)(cid:2)(cid:4)(cid:24)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:3)#(cid:4)(cid:18)(cid:8)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:24)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:3)V

the  market. 

It  is  difficult  to  assess  because  industry,  for  obvious
financial  reasons,  tends  to  be  very  secretive  about  their
investments in research in potential new products that can
  The  Pharmaceutical
eventually 
Research  and  Manufactures  of  America 
(PhRMA)
estimates that, in 1999, $20 billion of R&D were conducted
in  US  and  another  $3.9  billion  in  the  rest  of  the  world,
which  correspond  to  a  14.1%  increase  over  1998  (Rettig
2000). In 2001, it is estimated that $70 billion were invested
in health R&D globally, of which $30 billion originated from
public funding. The estimates for private sector investment
vary  between  $40  billion  to  $55-60  billion  (Keusch  and
Nugent 2001).  The increase in private over public funding
is  important  because  it  seems  that  public  sector  funded
research is more likely than private sector funded research
to  address  the  specific  health  problems  of  the  developing
countries  (Keusch  and  Nugent  2001).  In 1992,  while  50%
of  the  global  health  R&D  was  undertaken  by  private
industry, less than 5% of the money was spent on diseases
specific  to  less  developed  countries  (Webber  and  Kremer
2001).

the 

this 

investment  of 

But,  how  much  of 
total
pharmaceutical  R&D  is  specifically  destined  to  clinical
research?  In 2000, an amount of W3(cid:4)"(cid:14)(cid:21)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11), of which 70%
came  from  industry,  was  invested  in  clinical  research
(Komesaroff  and  Kerridge  2002).  There  are  about  60,000
clinical trials currently underway worldwide funded with this
money (Djulbegovic 2001).

.(cid:23)"(cid:24)(cid:28)(cid:25)(cid:1)/0(cid:1)(cid:6) #(cid:28)(#(cid:30)(cid:25)(cid:24)(cid:22)(cid:23)(cid:30)#!
(cid:23)(cid:20)$(cid:24)(cid:21)(cid:22)(cid:28)1(cid:1)(cid:28)#(cid:20)2(cid:1)#(cid:20)$(cid:1)(#(cid:28)2(cid:25)(cid:22)
(cid:1)(cid:21) #(cid:28)(cid:25)(cid:1)%(cid:3)(cid:8)(cid:13)(cid:6)â(cid:1)344/&

As  seen  in  Fig  1,  while  the  Pharmaceutical  industry  is
ranked as one of the most  profitable,  the  market  share  of
the developing world accounts for less than 8% of the total.

192

Africa is expected to account for just 1.3% of pharmaceutical sales during this year, so it is not
a  market  share  likely  to  influence  investment  decisions  (UNDP  2001).  The  market  share  in
Latin America and Eastern Europe, however, are anticipated to increase in the near future.

Industry  is  also  devoting  non-profit  funding  for  research  in  developing  countries.  Both  within
and  outside  the  pharmaceutical  sector  there  are  visible  efforts  to  address  global  inequalities
and the  needs  of  poorer  countries.  Bill  and  Melinda  Gates  Foundation  paid  and  awarded,  in
2000,  grants  for  a  total  of  $1200  million  for  global  health  research  projects.  Grants  awarded
included  funding  for  the  development  of  a  vaccine  for  leishmaniasis,  funding  for  a  feasibility
study to improve manufacturing and delivery of vaccines in Russia, support for research aimed
at  the  reduction  of  child  mortality  and  funding  to  promote  the  discovery  and  development  of
antimalarial medicines32.  GlacoSmithKline, for example, has more than 20 active R&D projects
for  medicines  to  treat  diseases  prevalent  in  developing  countries.  It  has  been  researching
vaccines for HIV, tuberculosis and malaria, has three anti-malarial products at various stages of
development  and  clinical  projects  are  underway  with  a  new  combination  product  and  novel
proteases inhibitor for HIV/AIDS, along with research efforts to discover medicines with novel
mechanisms (GlaxoSmithKline 2001).

 +(cid:1) â(cid:8)(cid:20)(cid:4)(cid:24)(cid:10)(cid:11)#(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:4)"(cid:3)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:6)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:8)(cid:9)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:16)V

As  discussed,  many  companies  are  increasing  their  clinical  trials  in  developing  countries.
Figure 2 compares the total number of trials tracked down by FDA from 1990 to 1995 vs. the
number from 1996 to September 2000.  Thus âabove 200â means that the country had at least
200 more trials over the second half of the decade than in the early 90s. The growth illustrated
is only a small window on the total rise in trials because the FDA data captures less than 10%
of the overseas trials (Cohen 2000).  The trend correlates with the areas where new sites of
Contract  Research  Organisations,  CROs  (discussed  in-depth  in  following  sections),  are
emerging.

.(cid:23)"(cid:24)(cid:28)(cid:25)(cid:1)30(cid:1)(cid:14) (cid:25)(cid:1)"(cid:28)(cid:27)5(cid:22) (cid:1)(cid:27)(cid:26)(cid:1)$(cid:28)(cid:24)"(cid:1)(cid:22)(cid:28)(cid:23)#!(cid:21)(cid:1)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:20)$(cid:24)(cid:30)(cid:22)(cid:25)$(cid:1)#(cid:28)(cid:27)(cid:24)(cid:20)$(cid:1)(cid:22) (cid:25)(cid:1)5(cid:27)(cid:28)!$(cid:1)(cid:23)(cid:20)(cid:1)(cid:22) (cid:25)(cid:1)(cid:21)(cid:25)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:20)$(cid:1) #!(cid:26)
(cid:27)(cid:26)(cid:1)(cid:22) (cid:25)(cid:1)64(cid:21)(cid:1)$(cid:25)(cid:30)#$(cid:25)7(cid:1)(cid:1)(cid:12)(cid:27)(cid:24)(cid:28)(cid:30)(cid:25)0(cid:1).(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:1)$#(cid:22)#)#(cid:21)(cid:25)%(cid:9)(cid:27) (cid:25)(cid:20)(cid:1)3444&

A  more  general  distribution,  according  to  a  recent  US  survey  among  330  researchers
conducting  clinical  trials  outside  worlwide,  is  depicted  in  Figure  3.    The  survey  was
commissioned  by  the  US  National  Bioethics  Advisory  Commission  (Kass  and  Hyder  2001).
Interestingly, the distribution of clinical trials that comes out of the survey (figure 3) differs from
the distribution pattern according to the FDA database (figure 2).  The differences may be due
to the fact that most of the researchers that answered the survey were from the public sector
(academia and government) while the FDA data base would represent better the private sector
(all  companies  that  want  permission  to  commercialise  a  new  drug  have  to  file  for  FDA
approval).

.(cid:23)"(cid:24)(cid:28)(cid:25)(cid:1)80(cid:1)(cid:4)(cid:25)"(cid:23)(cid:27)(cid:20)(cid:21)(cid:1)(cid:27)(cid:26)(cid:1)(cid:22) (cid:25)(cid:1)(cid:13)(cid:25)(cid:31)(cid:25)!(cid:27)(cid:29)(cid:23)(cid:20)"(cid:1)9(cid:27)(cid:28)!$(cid:1)9 (cid:25)(cid:28)(cid:25)(cid:1)(cid:19)(cid:25)#!(cid:22) (cid:1)(cid:4)(cid:25)(cid:21)(cid:25)#(cid:28)(cid:30) (cid:25)(cid:28)(cid:21)(cid:1)(cid:9)(cid:27)(cid:20)$(cid:24)(cid:30)(cid:22)(cid:25)$

A recent study analysed the US Food and Drug Administrationâs (FDA)  data  base on  foreign
clinical  investigators  who  are  conducting  drug  research  under  Investigational  New  Drug
Applications  (INDs).  These  applications  are  voluntary  for  those  carrying  the  clinical  trials
outside the US while obligatory for US-based trials.  According to this study, as seen in Figure
4,  the  number  of  foreign  clinical  trials  investigators  conducting  drug  research  overseas
increased 16-fold in the past decade (Rehnquist 2001). In 1990, 271 of  these  foreign  clinical
investigators  were  in  the  FDAâs  database.    By  1999  the  number  grew  to  4458.    Incidentally,
FDA inspections of foreign clinical investigations conducting drug research also grew, from 22
in 1990 to 64 in 1999 (less than 3 fold).

32 See http://www.gatesfoundation.org

(cid:1)(cid:1)(cid:1)(cid:1)(cid:1)(cid:1)(cid:1)(cid:1).(cid:23)"(cid:24)(cid:28)(cid:25)(cid:1)<0(cid:1)(cid:8)(cid:27)(cid:20)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:12)(cid:1)(cid:9)!(cid:23)(cid:20)(cid:23)(cid:30)#!(cid:1)(cid:11)(cid:20)(cid:31)(cid:25)(cid:21)(cid:22)(cid:23)"#(cid:22)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:21)(cid:1)(cid:14)(cid:28)#(cid:30)2(cid:25)$(cid:1))1(cid:1).(cid:13)(cid:7)

YEAR

The number of countries where drug research is conducted has enlarged from 28 in 1990 to 79
in  1999.    While  research  is  still  conducted  in  countries  with  a  history  of  hosting  this  type  of
research,  countries  in  regions  such  as  Eastern  Europe,  Latin  America,  and  East  Asia  are
emerging  as  desirable  locations  for  sponsors  to  conduct  research  (see  Figures  2  and  3).
Sponsors attest to this growth: in 1992, 61 premarket clinical research protocols were approved
in  Hungary  and  the number  almost  tripled  to  178  in  1999  (the  number  of  approvals  includes
trials  that,  despite  approval,  may  have  never  been  launched  or  may  have  stopped  prior  to
completion) (Allen 2000).

The trend observed from other non-US perspectives is similar.  The proportion of international
trials is constantly increasing in Czech Republic, for example.  In 2000, of the 287 approved or
notified  trials,  224  (78%)  were  international,  while  this  number  was  only  48  in  1998  (Perlik
2001).

As another example, Merk & Company now conducts approximately 35% of all its clinical trials
overseas, a percentage that is increasing steadily (Schmidt 2001).

(cid:22)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)#â*(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:26)+(cid:8)#&!(cid:27)!#â&(cid:8)(cid:28)%!â&*(cid:8)!(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:4)â(cid:28)!(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:19)(cid:31)(cid:30)%!#â(cid:0)(cid:0)

In the past, few clinical trials were performed in Latin America because the regionâs healthcare
systems and potential investigators pools were not up to the standards used in North America
and  Western  European  trials.  This  view  has  changed  substantially  in  recent  years  as  Latin
American  governments  have  improved  health  care  and  related  regulations.  According  to
industry  observers,  providing  market  conditions  are  favourable,  an  increase  of  number  of
clinical  trials  per  year  as  much  as  tenfold  can  be  expected  over  the  next  five  years
(CenterWatch  2000).  Currently,  R&D  spending  in  Latin  America  is  estimated  by  PhRMA
members to be only 1,6% of total global R&D expenditures.

33 Source: http://www.fast-track.com/pdfs/ClinicalTrialsLatinAmerica.pdf

Latin  America  offers  a  large  source  of  potential  trial  patients  who  for  the  most  part  can  be
considered  as  âtreatment  naÃ¯veâ  (not  on  other  medications  that  could  interfere  with
experimental  treatments).  It  represents  an  impressive  market  potential  for  pharmaceutical
drugs (figure 5).

.(cid:23)"(cid:24)(cid:28)(cid:25)(cid:1)>0(cid:1).(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:25)(cid:30)#(cid:21)(cid:22)(cid:1)(cid:27)(cid:26)(cid:1)(cid:22) (cid:25)(cid:1)(cid:17)#(cid:22)(cid:23)(cid:20)(cid:1)(cid:7)((cid:25)(cid:28)(cid:23)(cid:30)#(cid:20)(cid:1)(#(cid:28)2(cid:25)(cid:22)(cid:1))1(cid:1)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:24)(cid:20)(cid:22)(cid:28)1(cid:1)%344>&

Peru

The three largest markets for pharmaceutical drugs, Brazil, Argentina and Mexico, are also the
most  established  in  conducting  clinical  trials  over  the  last  five  years  and  have  enacted  clear
controlling processes and relevant legislation. All three of these countries require authorisations
of  clinical  trials  by  ethics  committees  and  regulatory  authorities.  According  to  researchers  of
DataEdge, the number of clinical trials executed in Latin America for US authorisations (based
on the â1572 formsâ filed34) increased over tenfold from 1995 to 2000 (figure 6).

.(cid:23)"(cid:24)(cid:28)(cid:25)(cid:1)?0(cid:1)(cid:6)(cid:25)(cid:28)(cid:30)(cid:25)(cid:20)(cid:22)#"(cid:25)(cid:1)(cid:27)(cid:26)(cid:1)"(cid:28)(cid:27)5(cid:22) (cid:1)(cid:23)(cid:20)(cid:1)(cid:30)!(cid:23)(cid:20)(cid:23)(cid:30)#!(cid:1)(cid:22)(cid:28)(cid:23)#!(cid:21)(cid:1)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:20)$(cid:24)(cid:30)(cid:22)(cid:25)$(cid:1)(cid:23)(cid:20)(cid:1)(cid:17)#(cid:22)(cid:23)(cid:20)(cid:1)(cid:7)((cid:25)(cid:28)(cid:23)(cid:30)#(cid:1)%/66>(cid:15)

conduct research in an ethical manner and according to FDA regulations

6+(cid:1) 5(cid:2)#(cid:4) (cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:4) (cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4) (cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:16)(cid:4) "(cid:3)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:24)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:4) (cid:24)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:3)(cid:4) (cid:26)(cid:7)(cid:3)H(cid:6)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:4) (cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4) (cid:18)(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:8)(cid:9)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:22)(cid:4) (cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:4) (cid:21)(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:16)

(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:18)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:18)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:6)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:3)(cid:16)V

The globalisation of industry-funded clinical trials can be attributed to a variety of factors (Rettig
2000; Rehnquist 2001):

â¢  open new commercial market for the products (when the country where drug are tested is

suitable beneficial of the drugs),

â¢  save time. Some diseases, such as pneumonia, are seasonal and strike in different regions
at different time of the year. Global seasonal patterns allow infectious disease to go on one
year round, which speeds the process of clinical evaluation,

â¢  provide non-limited number of patients (the lack of patients is often raised as the principal

reasons for cancelling or delay in the development of clinical research),
â¢  study drug effect among ethnic populations in the regions where they live

A  survey  by  two  Johns  Hopkins  University  researchers  of  more  than  500  US  and  foreign
pharmaceutical  researchers  regarding  the  ethics  of  research  in  developing  countries  was
carried in the period 1998-2000.  The survey found that the reasons put forward by researchers
to  justify  location  of  the  trials  in developing  countries  were  most  often  the  ease  of  access  to
large  number  of  patients  and  possibility  to  complete  clinical  trials  rapidly.    Some  of  the
investigators,  however,  overtly  admitted  that  an  important  reason  to  carry  the  trials  in  these
areas was to abide a less stringent regulatory framework (Kass and Hyder 2001).

According to the already-mentioned analysis of the FDA database (Rehnquist 2001), the main
reason  for  the  sponsors  to  use  these  new  sites  for  their  research  is  to  gain  access  to  large
number of subjects with a particular disease, especially those that are ânaive subjectsâ (have
not been treated for the disease being studied).  Yet another reason put forward is to develop a
market for the study drug in the event that it is approved by the FDA.  This was also reported
by 24 % of the researchers surveyed by Kass and Hyder (Kass and Hyder 2001).

For a pharmaceutical industry, the criteria for selecting a particular country for conducting the
clinical  trial  include  the  availability  of  suitable  participants,  the  availability  of  high  quality
collaborators (speaking native language), and appropriate infrastructure for delivery of clinical
care to the participants (NCB 2002).

As Wilmshurst claimed, the choice of carrying clinical trials in developing countries may have to
do  with  the  facts  of  lower  costs,  lower  risk  of  litigation,  less  stringent  ethical  review,  the
availability of populations prepared to give unquestioning consent, anticipated underreporting of
side effects because of lower consumer awareness and  the desire to create new markets for
the drugs (Wilmhurst 1997).

197

3+(cid:1) (cid:23)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:10)(cid:15)(cid:13)(cid:4)/(cid:3)(cid:16)(cid:3)(cid:10)(cid:7)(cid:15)(cid:2)(cid:4)(cid:25)(cid:7)(cid:22)(cid:10)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:16)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:16);(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:4)(cid:8)(cid:13)(cid:2)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:16)(cid:2)(cid:14)(cid:26)(cid:13)(cid:4)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:14)(cid:15)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:7)(cid:14)(cid:10)(cid:21)(cid:16)

As argued, clinical research is shifting to developing countries at the same time its is turning
from public to private funding.  The process of developing and testing new drugs is becoming
more costly and complex and the pharmaceutical industry is, in response, trying to find cheaper
and easier ways to conduct clinical trials, turning away from medical and academic centres to
an  entirely  new  industry,  the  so-called  contract  research  organisations  (CROs)  and  site
management  organisations  (SMOs).  The  CROs  are  engaged  in  the  management  of  clinical
trials for the pharmaceutical industry, including also biotechnology and medical device firms as
clients  (Rettig  2000).  The  SMOs  are  responsible  for  the  recruitment  of  investigators  and
patients.  They  work  on  behalf  of  the  pharmaceutical  industries  or  more  often  directly  with
CROs.

In 2000, CROs received in US 60% of the research grants from pharmaceutical companies as
compared  to  the 40%  for  academic  researchers  (Davidoff,  DeAngelis  et  al.  2001).  The  (cid:17)111
(cid:15)(cid:30)(cid:27)(cid:28)(cid:30)%Eâ(cid:28)#(cid:29)(cid:8)(cid:5)(cid:27)$ *(cid:28)%"(cid:8)(cid:21)!%(cid:30)#(cid:28)(cid:26)%" lists more than 500 US and foreign-based CROs35.  The  total
number of CROs worldwide is increasing every day and CROs are implanted in more and more
countries.  Also  in  2000,  the  worldâs  largest  CRO  which  is  currently  located  in  38  countries,
opened  offices  in  7  new  countries:  Chile,  Czech  Republic,  Greece,  Norway,  the  Philippines,
Romania and Thailand (Engel 2000). CROs are expanding their clinical trial services (and are
getting specialised per country) into Asia and Pacific (KII 2000), Eastern Europe and in Latin
America  (CenterWatch  2000),  but  also  Russian  (Allen  2000)  and  in  Baltic  countries  in  1998
(Centerwatch  2000).  The  largest  growth  in  the  implementation  of  new  CROs  is  occurring  in
Eastern  Europe,  Latin  America and  Russia  (Rehnquist  2001).  In  Latin  America,  for  example,
several of the largest CROs (ClinTrials, Covance, Quintiles, ICON,â¦) have opened offices in
the past recent years. The expected expansion of the number of clinical trials in Latin America
correspond to a need for expanded infrastructure, and more CROs can be expected to open
new offices there.

The  expansion  of  these  organisations  into  more  countries  suggests  that  these  countries  are
emerging as places were sponsors are currently conducting research or plan to in the future.

The CROs present several advantages. First, government and private sector have generated
an intensive search for efficiencies in the drug development cycle and industry had concluded
that  some  bottlenecks  can  be  managed  more  effectively  by  external  resources.  Second,  the
number of drugs in the development pipeline is increasing every year (estimated at 7.000 new
compounds in 1997) and private firms may find CRO an attractive way to escape the limits of
existing organisational capacity. Third, in the context of constant merge of companies, it may
be  easier  for a  merged  company  to  outsource  clinical  trials  than  to  integrate  two  R&D  units.
Fourth, CROs provide to the private industry an experienced place to conduct pre-clinical and
clinical  research.  Fifth,  in  the  context  of  globalisation  of  the  market  for  new  drugs,  the
harmonisation  of  European,  Japanese  and  US  drug  evaluation  procedures  has  created
opportunities  for  drug  firms  to  seek  regulatory  approval  in  various  national  markets
simultaneously rather than sequentially.

35 In 1998, the seven largest CROs in net revenues were Quintiles Translational Corporation, Covance
Inc., PARELEX International Corporation, Pharmaceutical Product Development Inc., Phoenix
International Sciences Inc., Kendle International Inc. and Clin Trials Research Inc.

198

                                                     
Finally,  CROs  might  have  developed  particular  therapeutic  expertise  which  is  attractive  to
drugs firms with limited experience in a given therapeutic area (Rettig 2000).

The SMOs and the CROs will often assume the responsibility for getting the trials approved by
an Institutional Review Board (IRB), which is required by national and international regulations.
IRBs approve the study protocol, the informed consent procedures and some other aspects of
the trial, including the compensation paid to patients. When the trial is based at a hospital or
academic institution, that same organisationâs IRB will approve and oversee the trial, but when
a CRO conducts the trial, it will generally use an independent and professional IRB to perform
this  service.  SMOs  and  CROs  are  working  to  comply  with  international  Good  Laboratory
Practices  (GLP),  Good  Clinical  Practices  (GCP),  Good  Manufacturing  Organisation  (GMP)
regulations, and International Standards Organisation (ISO) 9000 quality system standards.

The pharmaceutical industry has recognised the need to control costs and has discovered that
private non-academic research groups can do the job for less money and fewer hassles than
academics,  but  does  this  process  compromise  ethical  values?  (Davidoff,  DeAngelis  et  al.
2001). Typically, ethical review of industry-sponsored clinical trials conducted outside academic
medical centres is undertaken for-profit ânon-institutionalâ review boards.  Concerns have been
raised about the potential of this new system of managing clinical trials to compromise both the
scientific quality of clinical research and the protection of research participants (Miller and Shorr
2002).  In  view  of  the  ethically  questionable  features  of  several  cases,  specifically  the  use  of
placebo  in  the  face  of  known  effective  treatment  without  a  solid  methodologic  rationale,  has
raised concerns and requests for a more stringent regulatory system and additional safeguards
to  be  implemented.    Empirical  research  that  compares  industry-sponsored  clinical  trials  and
government-sponsored conducted by private or academic investigators has been requested by
some bioethicists (Miller and Shorr 2002).

Djulbegovic has shown that industry-sponsored trials are more likely to use a  placebo  or  no-
therapy control group (Djulbegovic 2001). This, as Halpern and Karlawish speculate, might be
because  clinical  trials  are  then  less  expensive,  a  smaller  sample  size  is  required,  and
regulatory agencies seem to be more favourable reviewing data compared with placebo than
with  another  active  compound  (since  it  is  usually  statistically  more  significant)  (Halpern  and
Karlawish 2000).

M. Angell, the former editor of New England Medical Journal, one of the doctors that raised the
flag in the 1997 HIV scandal, has called for the abolition of for-profit CROs and the turning back
to academic centres with armâs-length funding by industry. She claims the problem is  not so
much  the  source  of  the  funding  but  the  terms  of  it:  industry  ends  up  designing  the  study,
keeping  the  data,  writing  the  article  and  deciding  whether  its  published  which  gives  them
enormous control over the evaluation of their own drugs.  R. Gams, a major CRO executive,
defends the system noting it has many standard operating procedures in place, it is constantly
audited by quality assurance groups and the  scrutiny  it undergoes  is  beyond  the  standard  in
the academic world (Reynolds 2001).

199

(cid:31)+(cid:1) /(cid:3)(cid:22)(cid:6)(cid:21)(cid:10)(cid:13)(cid:8)(cid:7)#(cid:4)(cid:26)(cid:7)(cid:10)(cid:24)(cid:3)(cid:20)(cid:8)(cid:7)A

The brave new world of clinical trials research has sprung up so quickly and has become so
global that policymakers have to deal with complicated business, ethical and regulatory issues
that accompany the promising developments of this new enterprise. The globalisation of clinical
trials raises new problems for policy-makers. Have the countries selected for the clinical trials
developed adequate regulations? Are the clinical trials conducted in less developed countries
controlled by European or US institutions? How transparent are the procedures and results of
clinical trials funded by industrial pharmaceutical companies? Can an authorisation for a new
drug  in  an  industrialised  market  be  given  solely  on  the  basis  of  results  of  clinical  trials
conducted in developing countries? The regulatory framework has to adapt to the new situation
where  authorisations  for  marketing  of  new  drugs  might  be  submitted  on  the  basis  of  clinical
trials conducted in new sites.

At International level, the International Conference on Harmonisation (ICH)36, created in 1990,
has  the  commitment  to  increase  international  harmonisation and  to ensure  that good  quality,
safe  and  effective  medicines  are  developed  and  registered  in  the  most  efficient  and  cost-
effective manner. ICH has developed several guidelines documents37. In November 2000, the
Common  Technical  Document38(cid:8) (updated  version  in  September  2002)  was  released,
describing a common format for presenting study data in applications submitted for regulatory
review  within  USA,  Europe  and  Japan.  The  Common  Technical  Document  provides  a  set  of
international  standards  on  issues  including  informed  consent,  institutional  review  board,  and
regulatory requirements necessary wherever in the world clinical trials are conducted. They do
consider the multiple sites of clinical trials and the use of CROs. They stipulate that all clinical
trials need the favourable opinion of a institutional review board/independent ethic committee
before starting, and the  ultimate  responsible for  the  trial  is  the  sponsor,  independently of  the
use or not of CROs.

In the USA, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is the agency responsible to approve new
drug that enter the market. Two applications are generally submitted to FDA. The first one is
the Investigational New Drug Application (IND).  Sponsors  of  drug  research  submit  an  IND  to
FDA prior to the start of the research that will be conducted under FDA regulations (mandatory
for US clinical trials). The second one is the New Drug Application (NDA). It is submitted by the
sponsors,  after  the  research  is  complete,  to  obtain  FDA  approval  to  market  the  new  drug.
NDAs  can  contain  data  from  research  conducted  at  US  as  well  as  foreign  sites.  In  the  last
case,  FDA  requires  to  respect  the  standard  of  the  Declaration  of  Helsinki  or  host  countryâs
regulation if it provides a higher level of protection for the trial subjects.

FDA does regulate clinical trials conducted in third countries, but there are two different level of
requirements  for  US  or  non-US  based  research.  A  sponsor  can  start  clinical  trials  in  third
countries  with  only  the  authorisation  of  the  host  national  ethic  committee.  Data  will  be
presented after completion of the trial to the FDA. At this stage, FDA can then accept or refuse
the data but any flaws in the design and conduct of the trials from an ethical point of view might
have gone undetected until then.

36 International Conference on Harmonisation of Technical Requirements for Registration of Pharmaceuticals for
Human Use http://www.ich.org/
37 http://www.ich.org/ich5c.html#Efficacy, http://www.ich.org/pdfICH/e6.pdf
38 http://www.ich.org/ich5c.html#Efficacy

200

                                                     
Rehnquist (Rehnquist 2001) raised several other concerns: the lack of FDA inspections of the
foreign institutional review boards, the fact that sponsors do not necessarily have to present an
attestation39, the lack of review of monitoring of the progress of the trial, and the lack of regular
inspections due to high costs.

In  Europe,  the  equivalent  to  the  US  FDA  is  the  European  Agency  for  the  Evaluation  of
Medicinal  Products  (EMEA).  The  EMEA  has  requirements  regarding  the  conduct  of  clinical
trials submitted in marketing applications according to the Annex 1 to the directive 2001/83/EC
which  is  being  revised  at  present  (first  reading  of  the  European  Parliament  last  23th  October
2002). In terms of the authorisation for marketing of new drugs, a European equivalent of the
FDAâs  Investigational  New  Drug  Application  (IND)  does  not  exist  so  far.  This  process  is
managed by the individual Member States though it is now being harmonised by the mentioned
Directive 2001/83/EC and related guidelines. The proposals for this harmonisation, which aims
to centralise the drug authorisation procedure, consist of one Regulation and two Directives40.
EMEA will strengthen its role with the proposed changes.

Directive  2001/20/EC41  aims  to  harmonise  good  clinical  practices  in  the  conduct  of  clinical
trials.  The  Directive  establishes  specific  provisions  regarding  the  conduct  of  clinical  trials  on
human  subjects,  including  multi-site  trials.  Clinical  trials  can  only  start  after  approval  of  the
Ethics  Committee,  which  gives  opinions  on  the  protocol  design.  In  the  case  of  multiple  site
clinical trials a single opinion is given for each Member State concerned by the clinical trial. The
trials  carried  out  in  different  countries  must  then  follow  the  same  protocol.  Therefore,  the
protection of the patients (and the acceptance of placebo in the clinical trial protocol) should be
the same whatever the site the clinical trial takes place. This is an important difference between
clinical trials conducted in third countries for commercial authorisation in Europe or in USA.

The Directive and guidance documents mention also that a specific process will be designed
for  inspections  in  third  countries  (process  to  be  agreed  between  Member  States,  European
Commission  and  EMEA).  All  inspections  should  be  recorded  on  a  European  clinical  trial
database (EUDRACT database)42, operated by the European Commission, with limited access
for  EMEA  and  the  competent  authorities  of  the  Member  States.  The  document  (cid:21)(cid:30)(cid:28)â!&(cid:30)$
( !$â(cid:27)#(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:26)(cid:27)(cid:8)(cid:28)(cid:29)(cid:30)(cid:8)(cid:1) %(cid:26))(cid:30)â(cid:27)(cid:8)#&!(cid:27)!#â&(cid:8)(cid:28)%!â&*(cid:8)$â(cid:28)â/â*(cid:30)  stipulates  that  all  clinical  trials  for  which at
least one site falls within the territory of a Member State should be included.

39 In signing the attestation, the investigators commit to adhere to the study protocol,  to  personally  conduct  the
study, to inform  subjects  that  the  drugs  are  being  used  for  investigation  purposes,  to  meet  FDA  regulations  on
informed consent and Institutional Review board, to report adverse events, to report to the IRB any changes in the
study protocol or any unexpected problems.
40 - Proposal for a European Parliament and Council regulation and supervision of medicinal
products for human and veterinary use and establishing a European Agency for the
Evaluation of Medicinal Products
- Proposal for a European Parliament and Council directive amending Directive 2001/83/EC
on the Community code relating to medicinal products for human use, and
- Proposal for a European Parliament and Council directive amending Directive 2001/82/EC
on the Community code relating to veterinary medicinal products
The proposals are available at: http://pharmacos.eudra.org/F2/review/index.htm
41 Directive 2001/20/EC on the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member
States relating to the implementation of good clinical practice in the conduct of clinical trials on medicinal products
for human use. Available at
http://europa.eu.int/eur-lex/pri/en/oj/dat/2001/l_121/l_12120010501en00340044.pdf
42 http://pharmacos.eudra.org/F2/pharmacos/docs/Doc2002/July/eudractguideline_e6421.pdf

201

                                                     
The database does not specifically refer to trials conducted entirely outside Europe and, given
the  increase  in  clinical  research  conducted  worldwide,  there  is  a  risk  that  all  this  research
activity might end up lacking in the European database.

<+(cid:1) )(cid:8)(cid:14)(cid:11)(cid:13)(cid:16)(cid:4)(cid:26)(cid:8)(cid:7)(cid:4)(cid:15)(cid:8)(cid:11)(cid:15)(cid:21)(cid:6)(cid:16)(cid:14)(cid:8)(cid:11)

The amount of time and money that it takes to develop and test a new  therapeutic drug  has
increase  enormously  over  the  years.    Costs  have  grown  but  so  have  revenues,  making
pharmaceutical  industry  one  of  the  most  profitable  last  year.    The  increased  costs  of  the
development process reach their peak when it gets to the clinical phase and so a search for
less  expensive  set-ups  has  moved  clinical  trials  from  historically  more  often  used  (with  well-
developed  health-care  infrastructures)  Western  countries  to  less  developed  or  newly
industrialised countries.  This shift is not exclusively due to the attempt to lower the costs but to
logistical reasons (finding enough number of patients, opening new markets, etc).

The pharmaceutical industry is turning to developing countries.  The main reasons are: access
to large number of patients (especially ânaÃ¯ve subjectsâ), rapid recruitment (which shortens the
overall  process),  counter  seasons  for  diseases  (which  also  saves  time),  new  market
development,    and  lowering  total  costs.    More  altruistic  reasons  for  conducting  research  in
developing  countries  are  addressing  global  inequalities  (capacity  building  is  an  important
aspect) and attempting to find cures for diseases that are more prevalent there. More obscure
reasons  are  undergoing  a  less  stringent  ethical  review    (because  poor  countries  often  have
weak  research  infrastructure  and  regulatory  institutions),  the  availability  of  populations
prepared to give unquestioning consent, and better possibilities of using a placebo as control
for the study.

Another  important  trend  of  the  industry-sponsored  research  is  to  outsource  the  conduct  of
clinical  trials  to  entities  that  specialise  in  managing  this  type  of  trials,  the  contract  research
organisations (CROs).  This trend is giving raise to concerns by those who claim that ethical
review may be less stringent in this set-up outside academic medical centres.  The review in
these  trials  is  usually  undertaken  by  for-profit  ânon-institutionalâ  review  boards,  and  some
researchers have raised questions about the independence of such boards.

The regulatory framework for clinical trials is expected to adapt to the globalisation.  It has been
proposed, among other things, that the budget and number of international/national inspectors
need to be increased in order to secure the respect of good clinical practice in all clinical trials
conducted  worldwide.  It  has  also  been  suggested  that  more  information  on  all  these  clinical
trials  should  be  available  and  that  an  international  database  to  track  down  the  growth  and
location  of  the  trials  would  help  a  proper  monitoring.  Finally,  it  has  also  been  stressed  the
importance  of  the  host  countryâs  institutional  review  boards,  as  they  are  the  ones  that  can
effectively  guarantee a  proper  protection  of  the  trial  subjects  (especially  in  terms  of  informed
consent and all that revolves around this issue) in the long run.  More information, monitoring
and  capacity  building  (training,  grants  for  assisting  to  conferences,  technical  assistance)  of
these boards has been requested

202
